having the strength and ability to develop a debate and a comparison that also raises the issue of more resources and the issue of more quality and more flexibility in their use.
And this is the challenge that lies ahead of us.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the European Parliament is called upon, as we know, to express itself definitively on food information for consumers.
It should be said right away that it was an objectively laborious, long and controversial legislative process that could not be shortened.

It is in fact a matter of harmonizing Community food law through regulations aimed at making consumer information transparent, avoiding leading them to confusing or potentially harmful choices for their health.
The report by Mrs Sommer, which acknowledges the effort made to summarize the multiple needs, aims to remedy controversies and different information systems in force in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations still differ in the designations of the nature of food on sale, generating a different system from country to country, also fueling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
The European Commission's proposal aimed to give a new character to the current legislation, involving, on the one hand, the food industry and, on the other hand, consumers.
At the same time, the report commits the European food industry to clarify the mandatory indications and the indication and presentation of nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not help but adapt and innovate food legislation to better protect the food trade, while safeguarding it from increasingly invasive and wild international competition.

It is not new that we hear more often about the danger of food products that surreptitiously give names and indications that often do not meet the food requirements that are still sold as foods and benefits for human health.
Madam Commissioner, we wanted this oral question and a parliamentary resolution to clarify with the Commission that
In the context of the Stockholm Programme, the construction of a European legal culture, widespread throughout our territory, is very important.

And I would like to say right away that this is important, but also that in view of the communication that the Commission will have to produce on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify some concepts.
First of all, let the consultations start soon, the consultations of the Parliament, and let them arrive in the initial phase when the idea begins to be drawn up.
of these future projects because we don't arrive too late when the projects are already formulated quite thoroughly.
And I say this because we have some basic observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of individual states, is today a decisive step for the construction of Europe.
Because, by interpreting national rights in a European way, it provides the conditions for resolving conflicts and regulating the daily lives of citizens.
And thus it founds European citizenship, it founds a European sensitivity of all those who live on these territories so that they can touch with their own hands.
The advantages of introducing European elements in all the rights of the States and therefore, above all, in Community law, make citizens live better.
They offer real advantages to solve a series of problems that would otherwise remain unsolved.
And I would like to say with this that we would like to turn the plant around a bit.
For example, we would not agree that these projects are Erasmus-style, because the number of magistrates and lawyers involved in Erasmus-style projects would be.
It is very low, as it can only be due to the high costs of physical mobility in this field and therefore not very relevant in the overall context of the judiciary.
But the most important issue concerns the term familiarization of the courses that we have introduced in our document.
Judges are not schoolboys who sit on school benches and are taught lessons, they are mature, highly professional people, with little time available for this, not easily movable, but they bring

They need to have knowledge in themselves and they need to be stimulated so that this knowledge is measured with the new problems of European law and European culture, creating conditions for exchange that are predominantly virtual rather than virtual.

Physical, using technologies, the network and the various opportunities that can determine these exchanges, and starting not so much from a general approach, but from individual cases, from individual problems that magistrates and lawyers face.
which are new and which must stimulate the professional growth of these legal professionals within a real stimulus.
to contribute to the autobiographical reflection of their experience, of what they have learned, to respond to the challenges that Europe is posing in positive terms.
As you can see, Mr. President, Commissioner, we intend to put something new into the tradition of the courses that have been done so far and that seem to us to be ineffective for this purpose.

We need to know how much funding is available and what it is, and express a doubt about the idea, as it was written in the communication, of a central European institution that governs this process because we are in favor of a bottom-up movement and not centralization.
This is a new setup.

However, what we want to mean is that if we do not form a European mentality among magistrates, among lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who ask for it, we will not make Europe.
So this is not just an important card for European justice, it is an important card for the entire development of European unity.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of bus passengers aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly the disabled or those with reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on bus passenger rights and should guarantee passengers, as is the case in the railway and air transport sectors.
The position at the second reading is aimed at establishing a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the line of the rapporteur, whom I thank for the excellent work done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and necessary to guarantee the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as already decided in the first reading by the Parliament.

The issue of passenger rights information is equally important. It would be useful to provide passengers with information on matches with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between bus and rail passenger transport services.

As for disabled people with reduced mobility, maximum protection must be guaranteed, and I would propose a twenty-four-hour deadline instead of forty-eight, in order to request assistance as well as greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of the tools that guarantee the mobility of people with otherwise qualified conditions in case of loss or damage.
Moreover, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be eliminated and existing infrastructures improved to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all to improve the travel conditions of passengers.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteur Sterks, who has done an excellent job on this report, which deals with how to extend the free movement of maritime transport within the European Union.
I agree with the rapporteur on the purpose of this directive, namely to exempt all maritime transport within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make the transport of goods by sea more attractive and to use it in an optimal way.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between member states will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost the sea freight traffic, which currently represents less than ten percent of the total.
To this day, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore be put into operation as quickly as possible, because it would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Moreover, interoperability is important for real administrative simplification. In fact, sending information via email is not entirely efficient and is useless if information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for the language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
This way, communication would be faster, causing less confusion and less administrative delays.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, first of all I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Mr. Kramer, because we all know that we have achieved a result that sometimes seemed hopeless.
I would like to remind you that this dossier was really considered a dossier at risk of conciliation procedure.
So we also heard from the Commissioner's words that it is clear to everyone that we are facing a complex job that has taken a lot of time.
Just think of a directive from 1996, which this work brings us to the fifth and most important amendment of the industrial emissions directive.
I believe that these few data alone tell us about all the shortcomings and even the defects of this legislation.

A directive that is difficult to implement, I would like to remind you that nine member states are affected by infringement procedures and with an scope of application so extensive that it sometimes even seems inappropriate.

We must not hide that all this has involved a lot of effort, it has required renouncements from all the institutions involved, from all the political groups, from all the national delegations and it has put us in front of really difficult choices.

However, I am here tonight to say with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results in protecting competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
On the one hand, we have a directive that imposes common obligations on all member states, but on the other hand, a directive that also allows the necessary flexibility.

I really hope that the results of this recast will be, in the immediate future, a reduction in administrative burdens and, in the medium term, an improvement in environmental performance and the strengthening of the European industry.
Mr. President, I would like to highlight the situation in which the crisis poses a reality in which for too long it has not been given the importance it deserved.

That is, the instability in Central Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, are proving to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has suffered in the last month from very tough clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of inter-ethnic hatred that will make the stabilization of the country even more difficult than it was before.
The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as already mentioned, is to assist the Kyrgyzstan as much as possible in three ways.
emergency supplies and the reconstruction of destroyed homes. Second, through the longest possible economic aid for the European Union within the framework of its
Central Asia strategy and the tools implemented in this context, through political support to support the process of returning to constitutional legality and the realization of a true rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, which was held in crisis on June 28, in obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road to returning to constitutional order.

The electoral process of June 28, among other things, received a positive judgment from the OSCE observation mission, which obviously took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of Kyrgyzstan will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than towards a presidential system.
This will perhaps allow for a better account of the varied ethnic composition of the country and the need to gather the consent of the various components of such a fragmented and composed country.
The European Union and Crimea are bound by a partnership and cooperation agreement that provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
We hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a democratically elected Parliament.
In the immediate future, the crisis, as already mentioned, needs stability and our political and economic help. We try not to be poor in both.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, today nobody voted. Today we also have a rotating presidency in the hands of a government that is distrusted by its own citizens.
This would be enough to understand why Europe is experiencing a deep crisis, a Europe that is now a political paradox in the hands of a political elite in which citizens do not recognize themselves.
The non-Belgian Presidency's programme talks about structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability and competitiveness, and the elected instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
However, the current crisis should push Europe to use ingredients that are quite different from those that led to failure.

A general rethinking is necessary because the crisis is not the mirror of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that European propaganda would like to administer as a cure.
Today, Europe is a huge building that collapses on itself due to the weight of democracy, centralism and obstacles to free enterprise.
To get out of the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more concreteness and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inevitably accelerate the decline.
Mr. President, thank you, I apologize. I would like to emphasize in this speech how the progressive erosion of the income of European farmers at the expense of the growing.
The agro-industrial sector's profit margins are creating a worrying economic marginalization of agricultural workers, with consequent cessation of the exercise of the same activities.
A change of direction is therefore necessary, which the European Commission itself recognizes and which the report for examination in the Chamber this morning
The approval of the House this morning, to which I want to express my support, highlights with broad motivations and suggestions also of a legislative and behavioral nature.
It is necessary to fight against global speculation on raw materials and to guarantee the security of supplies.

In addition, better price transparency must be guaranteed, which not only provides justice and dignity to farmers, but also corrects the strong imbalances in terms of negotiating power and avoids abuses between different operators.
Agriculture must reconfirm itself as the sector of economic and social stability and regain power in the commercial context of the European Union.
Mobilism and short-sightedness is the diagnosis of the malaise that affects Europe 27 today.

Immobility because if in Italy one in four young people is unemployed and in the Eurozone there are sixteen million unemployed, it is also because, according to the rumor of Euro propaganda in recent months, no concrete action has been taken.

Shortsightedness because Europe, in pointing out the way out of the crisis, not only represented the usual recipe, but completely lost sight of the more authentically territorial dimension of the economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by putting the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its peculiar cultural vocations, European development and employment policies can restart, nourishing the natural energies that every geographical area expresses, districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local authorities and prioritize subsidiarity, protecting a heritage made of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the European compass needle does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the euro project is a certainty.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in the construction of a Europe of rights, freedom of information, information pluralism and information independence have a central place.
Did the Commissioner notice that there is a European Union country, among others, a founding member of the European Union with the Treaty of Rome, where there is no European Union?
There is no pluralism of information where a Council President directly or indirectly controls public and private television and printed paper.
What democratic electoral competition can there be in a country where a Council President or a political party controls the media?
What democracy can we have in a country where a law is to be passed every day that does not allow journalists to publish judicial news?
Other than Watergate, other than the press, guardian of the regime, a living room boy. What democratic country is it where the internet wants to be put under control?
What democratic country is it where those who stand in the way of the single thought are put in the corner and the free expression of thought and dissent is not guaranteed?

We are not describing Bocassa's Sudan, Ceausescu's Romania, or Berlusconi's Italy, where unfortunately this also happens because the European Commission does not have the courage to make itself heard with regard to the member states.
The completion of the internal postal services market by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be

It would be appropriate for the Commission to carry out an impact assessment, as some of my predecessors have mentioned, of the opening of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountainous or rural areas, so that they can receive the post regularly, and what tools does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure that this happens?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is the member states that must apply the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that part of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, until today, the Commission has said little about it, despite the Treaty of Lisbon requiring the Commission itself to inform Parliament in a timely manner.
As is known, Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it shown to date that it is behaving in line with international law.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants who were inhumanly detained in the Libyan center of Brac or the closure of UNHCR offices, but above all I think of what happened last week when a Libyan Republic motorway opened fire.

against an Italian fishing boat of the Marina di Mazzara del Vallo, present in international waters, with the justification of the presence of illegal immigrants on board, a very serious justification that makes us think that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy, which

It provides, among other things, the rejection of immigrants to Libya without provisions relating to the right to request asylum and individual examinations on a case-by-case basis of individual situations, and also contains the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.
Since part of the agreement is also secret in this case, I wonder if the Commission is aware of the content, if it does not consider it necessary in this specific case to ask for explanations.
The possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on boats if there is a suspicion of transporting irregular immigrants.

Mr. President, on an economic level, it is positive for Europe to deepen trade relations with strongly growing neighboring countries. However, the EU has always conducted, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries, taking into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must then assert these clauses with firm determination towards Turkey, a country that is re-Islamizing, where the condition of women is gradually getting worse.
women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists, just remember the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovanese.

In the report, the Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is trying to take on in the Arab world.

friendship that Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups like Hamas. Anyway, if trade policy is to be, it is, but this should never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, this measure aims to strengthen and rationalize the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious objectives proposed by the McEwan reports, which amend regulation seven hundred and twenty-six and directive two thousand one hundred and eighty-three respectively.
Thanks to a tight and efficient consultation between the Council and the European Parliament and the parliamentary committees responsible for the matter.
to come to discuss today a proposal that aims to improve the Community pharmacovigilance system and to perfect the consistent and multi-year activity of the European Union in this sector.

Simplification, transparency and rationalization can be considered key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health, based on harmonized standards throughout Europe.

It refers to a wide range of interventions ranging from a better definition of the roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational subjects concerned to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient.

It recognizes a key role in the system, in strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicines, in simplifying communication, registration and evaluation activities of alleged negative side effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system must be improved, also thanks to closer collaboration at European, national and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three levels will ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding the side effects of medicines.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information for patients, national authorities and healthcare workers.
Mr. President, it is precisely these days that the European Union's objectives have been taken here in Brussels.

Many representatives of municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems that affect the lives of our cities, the old and new needs that affect workers, families, small and large production companies.
The economic crisis that has hit our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to give adequate answers to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has been, on many occasions, the only concrete tool in the hands of the territories to try to give answers.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, for all regions, an essential lever for the European integration process.
Now we are redefining this policy for after 2013, so we are at a turning point.
This is why it is vital to avoid some risks.
The first fundamental one is that of its renationalization, it would be a serious step backwards.

Then, in the construction of the funding budget, it is necessary to ensure an adequate distance, both with regard to the weaker realities and with regard to the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to make the ability to sanction those who have not been.
We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
The road to a Europe that is worthy of women is still long and difficult.
Statistics speak clearly. The global crisis has hit the labor market, putting women's employment to the test, which in 2008 was further reduced by seven tenths of a point.

Despite provocations that periodically fill a decreasing consensus on the topic of equal opportunities and employment, concrete measures have not yet been adopted to guarantee women a real realization as a worker and as a mother.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not just change its label periodically.

So the directive that aligns the maternity leave institution in Europe is good, but the choice to treat the complementary and equally important paternity leave, on the margins of this matter, in the same report, is inefficient.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.
Mr. President, the rapporteur of the Development Committee, Mr. Mitchell, asked me to replace him because he cannot be present today.
I thank him for the work done with his usual punctuality and for the quality of his proposals, which have received the favorable, I would say unanimous, opinion of the Development Commission.
As far as I can say, but especially as far as my colleague Michel has done so far, I am convinced that the report can be voted on by a large majority.
But now I come to the report.
In 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905 of 2006, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.

With this proposal, the Commission had asked the Parliament to approve an amendment that would allow non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal we accepted.
But the cooperation and development regulation also contains the implementation rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules provide that when the Commission needs to provide funding, it is required to follow the comitology procedures.

This means that the Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, in the event that the Commission exceeds its competences, the Parliament can then adopt resolutions in order to ask the Commission to change the decisions in question.

From 2006 to the present day, the Parliament has considered that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but only in three of these cases the Commission has in fact modified or withdrawn its proposal for a decision.
After the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Development Committee proposed to apply the delegated act procedure provided for in Article 290 of the Treaty of Lisbon.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, the Parliament would have a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in some well-defined cases, the Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions.
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

It is a choice that falls to the legislator, and then to which sectors to give priority in funding: education, health, environmental protection, the ability of good governance, the development of small businesses.
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and subjects in which the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
This is where the legislator must give precise indications to the executive.
And this is exactly the direction in which I believe the demands of European citizens are finally heading.
I really hope that there will be the greatest possible consensus for this report by Mr. Mitchell.
to the rapporteur. On the policy

Integrated maritime policy requires overcoming the phase of good intentions and giving a new impetus to a strategy that will represent a driver of growth and development of the European Union, making up for the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, in the fight against climate change and against pollution.
Just this morning, our colleague Pirillo reminded the Parliament of another catastrophic event that occurred in the city of Paola, in Calabria, in the past few days.

The Commission will have to show concreteness, operating not only with governance tools, but also implementing timely legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past mistakes, due to an often too sectoral approach.
There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the middle of a difficult and challenging path that cannot tolerate loads of attention and that needs adequate investments.

participatory governance mechanisms, both at the inter-institutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, including the Mediterranean, due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will be essential to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage of all coastal states, based on the principle of

Otherwise, the increasingly widespread practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive or similar economic zones of the Mediterranean Sea, in addition to not being in line with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would make the idea of effective and shared governance fall.

I would like to remind you that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya led to a real armed attack on a European fishing boat, and it would be wrong to claim that this is a Libyan-Italian affair.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank Mrs. Meissner for the report on the integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding and to protect coastal regions, as well as to promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial field.
This is why cooperation between small and large ports that are located on the same sea basin should be encouraged, and this can promote a more fluid trade exchange.
Moreover, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and back-to-port infrastructures, especially ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely port safety.

It is necessary to have a homogenization of all safety measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and avoid unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, in order to guarantee greater safety, have to face higher costs.
Mr. President, thirty years ago, Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Saharawi people, today it denies that there is disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara there are deaths and injuries from a population that only claims the right to live in freedom in their own land.
Morocco has essentially closed its borders to anyone who can witness these events.
No information and no deputies.
Access has been prohibited by a French deputy and our colleague Meyer.
Europe is passively assisting
There is no sign of the Commission's communication that makes us subordinate to the UN mediation, which continues to fail, as in the last thirty years.
There is no position taken by Ms. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
We need to react with a position from the Parliament.
We must react towards Morocco by interrupting any initiative on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of fishing agreements.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my speech is not intended to be the usual Eurosceptic rhetorical exercise, but an impulse for the EU to start paying more attention to the content than to the container and to abandon propaganda in favor of concreteness.
After the Lisbon strategy failed, Europe came up with a new slogan, EU 2020, but in fact it did not provide any innovative answers to employment problems.

The data confirms that the unemployment rate in Europe is 9.6 and the youth rate is 22. In Italy, the third net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young people without employment.

In the Europe I would like, there should be no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but efficient investments so that the training offer prepares professionals for the sectors of the internal market where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in vocational training, which is a symbol of the excellence of our territories.
The world of craftsmanship offers a potential for employment and a unique knowledge heritage, which must be entrusted with the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Madam President of the Council, the European will to set ambitious goals in view of the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to pursue with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will determine the future of our planet.
But that is exactly why, dear colleagues, we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The international negotiations preparatory to the Cancun conference, as far as we know, not only have not made significant progress towards a global agreement, but have also confirmed distrust and resistance to the commitments made in Copenhagen.
It has already been mentioned, but I would also like to mention China here.
For example, China is allowed to increase its emissions by five billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset by
And maybe not even, but an attempt to compensate only with a reduction of one hundred percent of European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only makes the proposal for an unconditional thirty percent reduction, which we strongly oppose, unreasonable, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at least risky and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and draw suggestive but unrealistic scenarios where unknowns inevitably reflect on the size of the costs.

The hope is that the European Union will bring a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal to Cancun, because it is always and in any case preferable to have an agreement that gives concrete and perceptible results rather than a proposal that is not a realistic proposal.

expectations inevitably destined to failure and to make the efforts of governments on major environmental issues less and less credible in the eyes of international public opinion, which would be a damage that is difficult to repair.

Mr. President, I have only one regret in this Chamber tonight that we are discussing the Sahrawis only because the Moroccans invaded the tent outside of the UN, and this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
The Parliament should have matured itself the will to discuss this issue, which has been rotting on international tables for thirty years.
This is the most relevant political fact.
We were forced to act of violence, not because we decided to guarantee human rights on our own.
Because what is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there must be a referendum for self-determination?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong part of the relations that we must strongly and with all the consequent acts ask that there is a will that can no longer be postponed.
We must try to create the conditions so that the Minuso mission is not alone in creating the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must try to use all the means available to the European Union to condition this event and to ensure that this referendum does justice to the thirty years of suffering of a people.
Mr. President, apart from this issue, I would like to raise a problem with the Presidency.
I believe that some people still do not fully understand what the role of the European Parliament is after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am forced to raise a fundamental problem here. Transport Commissioner Callas repeatedly refuses to meet the Sky and Space Board to discuss the CESAR project, which is of interest to everyone from the economic, environmental and safety point of view.

I invite the Presidency to summon Commissioner Callas to the chamber and explain what program it intends to carry out in this sector, which is extremely delicate and important for the European Parliament.

Dear colleagues, the report under discussion certainly contains some positive elements. The general direction is that of simplifying procedures, streamlining bureaucratic steps for third-country workers with regular residence permits in the Member State.

However, just as a focus for reflection, I would like to recall that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are unemployed due to the structural deficiencies of the European production system and as a result of a crisis that does not seem to be over.

Even before it is the case for third-country nationals who stay in our countries, Europe should be committed to implementing economic, political and social measures that help our citizens find or re-enter work.
If Europe can give its citizens work, it will create solid social foundations to adequately receive migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first of all, to make Europe grow on its own feet and with its own strength.
Our countries will then have the
Mr. President, today access to employment is only regulated for some specific categories of third-country nationals.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must take action to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals legally staying within the Member States and beneficiaries of the qualification of refugee or person in need of international protection, in accordance with Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to avoid a growing demand, for example, for seasonal staff just because they are paid less or because they have different, lower costs, compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.
For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinationals move their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and self-employed workers are included in this directive.
Making differences will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, human trafficking, according to estimates by international organizations and police forces, is now the second source of profit for organized crime worldwide after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that about thirty million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution and forced labor.
This means that, first of all, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestinity, against crime that generates crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this proportion, Europe must rightly take drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.
In the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between member countries and police forces is necessary, but above all, the certainty of penalties against traffickers.

They are exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find decent living conditions, they live in poverty and despair and are ready to do anything to leave their land to the promise of a better life that will not come true.

Europe, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must then make more and more scrupulous efforts so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their countries.
Let's help them at home, it must be the inspiring principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed, in addition to repression, also to prevention.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as Vice-President of the Development Committee, I am concerned with the problems of many countries, especially in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled, and sometimes even forgotten.

I just came back from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo last Sunday, where, in addition to institutional meetings of ritual, I wanted to meet the representatives of NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I have met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a tool of war, where armed groups continue to violate human rights.
to repeatedly practice mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civil society, especially against women, the elderly and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of Congo because it was a recent experience of mine, as I said, a very recent experience.
But the appeal I want to make is generally directed at the need for a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly increase the funds allocated to initiatives to protect women from rape and other forms of violence.
violence, such as genital mutilation, although a serious form of violation of women's human rights and physical integrity.
The European heritage label is of fundamental importance for a continent that includes most UNESCO sites and that
finally highlights those natural, archaeological, urban and cultural sites that have played an important role in the history, culture and integration of the European Union.
The approval of the brand is an important step for the Union's cohesion process and is also educational and training for cultural dialogue.
It can also be seen how this choice gives good hope to the new generations, who will increasingly have a common vision of European heritage that can accumulate them historically and culturally.

I would like to thank the rapporteur for her efforts and I extend my warmest congratulations to her for the negotiations with the Commission and for the effective success of this initiative, which is so important for the future of the preservation of the environment.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, represent a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious implications not only for those who suffer from it, but also for the health of others.
But the costs that must be borne for direct and informal care are high.
Alzheimer's disease is not only a problem for the people affected, but also for all those who take care of the patients themselves.
Therefore, a European response to the problem, global coordination among member states, and a synergy of concerted actions that concern above all the scientific and research fields are necessary.

Strengthening prevention, diagnosis and improvement of available, including innovative, treatments, as well as disseminating information among states on the results achieved within the same increasing citizens'level of knowledge of the disease.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the situation that the countryside, particularly the city of Naples, has been living in since universally known to the whole world, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue several times.

Faced with this paradoxical situation from the third world, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the point of view of Community law and what economic sanctions will possibly be combined against Italy in the event that the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in a short time.

I also ask if the Commission can provide in detail the data related to the European funds that have been managed so far by the Campania Region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, when we talk about an emergency, we usually talk about dramatic, extreme situations that, however, find a solution in a reasonable time.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, there is obviously something that is not working.

The Italian government has tried to do everything possible in recent years to resolve the long-standing issue of the waste collection and disposal cycle, but obviously if today the roads of Naples are invaded by tons of waste,
The main blame for the tons of garbage is on the local Campanian authorities and their total inability or lack of will to work to find a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania are in are due to the latency that has characterized municipalities, provinces and regions for many years in managing the waste cycle.
If separate collection is not done properly, the first indispensable element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send the army, it happened a few weeks ago, but other times before, to replace hundreds of suddenly and simultaneously ill-fated turbines, it obviously cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while things are going quite differently in the rest of Italy, for example in my region, Veneto, where separate collection has been done for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibility for the emergency falls on the people of the country.

on the Campanian politics and local administrators, and above all on the heavy connivance with the rubbish that has always sought and obtained huge profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local administrations.
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008, telling the Italians that the waste problem had been overcome, the European Union is doing well.
to block funds to Italy until an eco-friendly waste cycle is presented, based on waste recycling and composting.

And it is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which is once again based on uncontrolled landfills, such as those in Chiayano, Taverna del Rey, Terzigno, or even in the Vesuvio National Park, nor incinerators that produce death, cancer or a real health emergency.
Public money in the countryside, in the environmental emergency of these thirteen years, has consolidated criminal relations between politics, both left and right, entrepreneurs and the Camurra.

And environmental issues are resolved by criminalizing dissent, by criminalizing local communities, families and the territory, as the Italian government has done using the margana to repress those who defend nature and the territory.

International law is a political refugee who, fearing persecution on the grounds of race, religion, nationality, social affiliation or political opinions, is outside the country of which he is a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecutor.

Despite the coverage offered by France for years, we are talking about a multi-million-dollar criminal, executor or commander of four murders, who hid behind the pretext of political struggle to escape from life imprisonment.
It is shameful for a large country like Brazil to deny the extradition of a criminal, never repenting, by recognizing him as a political refugee.
Italian authorities and especially the families of the victims claim to see this criminal brought to justice.
Faced with President Lula's arrogance in denying extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the delivery of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening the suspension of cooperation agreements with Brazil.
to give concrete support to the Tunisian people and its transitional government, to relaunch a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been greatly neglected in recent years.
The explosion of the anger of young people and the poor in the Maghreb and Egypt is born from the unfair distribution of wealth and limitations on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

In North Africa, they regret and ask for more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work, and they look with amazement at the old, immobile European continent, unable to grasp the social transformations that have taken place in that area and to develop real policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, promote more dialogue, more collaboration and more real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejections of immigrants and through the violent collaboration of countries like Libya, more investments, more reception and more aid, more Euro-Mediterranean policy.
History asks us to do so.
The resolution approved today by a majority on the waste emergency in the countryside is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency becomes a European emergency and is a decision in favor of the Campanian citizens.
No to the allocation of funds that simply go to consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs and camorra, yes to European money if a credible plan is presented.
No to environmentally friendly waste management, no to uncontrolled landfills in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, but to recycling and environmentally friendly forms.
And it also says no to the criminalization of dissent from local communities, so yes to legality.

It is an important turning point, a warning for the Berlusconi government and the regional government led by Caldoro, which until now have only chatted and consolidated the crickets and the mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the problem of counterfeit medicines is a problem that is having an increasingly widespread incidence at the international and community level, both due to the increase in the number of cases and the increase in their improvement.
It is to these challenges that the report by Mr Mattias would like to respond, the result of long and laborious negotiations.
The report, to which we expressed our support, has defined a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, has taken into account
all actors, the moments and resignations of the pharmaceutical industry, safety, traceability, and obligations for the distribution chain, achieving a good compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which we must try to work to achieve the main goal of establishing stricter rules.
of counterfeit medicines, reaching a positive and more complete regulatory framework, able to safeguard the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people asking for a more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, they are protesting against corruption.
From the transition of soldiers and tanks, we need to move to true democracy, a new constitution, new elections, the abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights and freedoms.
It will be difficult.
There are those who think of using every means in the name of an idea.
We want to believe in the wonderful Egyptian people who have never experienced democracy.

We want a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious power and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes real rights, public health, social security, work.
Europe should support this path, but invest resources that can promote the true development of Egypt: never more dictatorships, never more misery, never more poverty.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean have, with this measure, started an even more urgent phase than the acts we have taken.
I believe that the act we are embodying today is much more important than the effects of the community regulation, that of 2006.

I think this also answers some of the limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has often left large fishing sectors to support the idea that yes, Europe does its part, but the other coastal countries do not.
I think it is strategic for us to address the issue in this dimension and with these characteristics.
I believe that the work done by my colleague Rivellini, which is very much shared, deserves a formal thank you here.
Nevertheless, I have a clear feeling that the fact that we are not able to resolve this issue at first reading and will reach the second reading
Especially on the interpretation of article twenty-eight of this regulation, it raises a question. The Parliament, on this occasion, takes the side of the Commission.

That is, the Parliament basically says that it is good that these delegated acts are in the Commission's hands, there is some resistance from the Council, among other things, today's absence is also a significant absence.
But this act makes the idea mature in Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fishing of this important sea, is also the future of fishermen.
But that being said, I think that the phase we are facing must centrally re-propose the idea of codecision.
These delegated acts have their own reason for being delegated and therefore are conferred today to the Commission, but international agreements must maintain its role in Parliament when they occur.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion, we have two problems: one is methodological and the other is in the merits of this case.

The method is that we are behaving through an artifice for which we thank Mr. Fraga, which is the oral question, to talk about something that should instead be a right of this Parliament after the Treaty of Lisbon.
I think this practice should end, we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a codecision process.
Codecision is such when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are having this debate, it is over, the treaty will move forward and we will say yes or no at the end.
Well, this method needs to be converted.

Instead, I just wanted to emphasize, and I agree with many of my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of fishing agreements, so that they are not just mere commercial agreements through which we buy cephalopods at one euro per kilo in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability and, above all, the impact on the economy of that country, understand how many jobs are being changed, understand what rate of innovation exists for artisanal fishing, understand the use of these resources.
It is not just a pure and simple trade, but a fishing agreement with all its implications.
Mr. President, the favorable vote expressed for the report by Mr. Rivasi is the result of an assessment of the management of the H1N1 flu.
2001, which is 2009-2010, aims to establish valid general criteria for conduct in any future global health emergency.
The report, following a long and positive reworking phase, makes cooperation, independence and transparency its main cornerstones.
It calls for greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, so that a harmonized and common risk management can be prepared.
The objectives are the evaluation of the strategies of the member states regarding the national plans for the management of the flu, including the supply of vaccines, the publication of names,
all the experts consulted by the European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media in charge of spreading public health messages.
That is why we voted in favor.

Mr. President, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been provisionally incorporated into EU legislation through annual regulations on fishing possibilities.
These concern conservation, management, exploitation, control and marketing measures for Mediterranean fishery and aquaculture products.
However, the permanent nature of these recommendations requires a more stable legal instrument for their implementation in Community law.
It was therefore appropriate to incorporate the recommendations in question through a single legislative act to which future recommendations could be added.
Today we have done this and this will improve legal certainty while constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM have the obligation to ensure full implementation of the agreed measures in accordance with the established high.

Timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make such international measures directly applicable to individuals or legal entities at the community level and to ensure the certainty of the right to action.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that the approval of the report by colleague Podimata represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced and stronger economic and fiscal policy in the European field.

It is now clear to everyone the urgency of equipping Europe, as a coordination between the twenty-seven countries, with economic and financial instruments that can govern the economy and not just suffer it.
For this reason, the proposal for taxation of financial transactions has had a great echo, a great discussion, and great attention.
The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this rule is an important and significant fact, because for the first time it was not pushed and instead a step forward was made.
I hope that the Commission and the Council will continue on this path.

Mr. President, I welcome the reports on equality between men and women and on female poverty in Europe and I am pleased that it was discussed today, when the hundredth anniversary of International Women's Day is being celebrated.

Despite Directive 2002/73/EC on equal treatment between men and women in terms of access to work, training, professional promotion and working conditions, further efforts still need to be made to achieve proper implementation.

It is enough to think that, despite the fact that the level of female education has increased a lot in recent years and the number of graduates is today higher than that of graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female sectors and are often less paid and occupy fewer positions of responsibility in all spheres of society.
The lack of access to care services for employees such as children, the disabled and the elderly, adequate leave schemes and flexible work formulas prevent women from working.

I would like to conclude by reminding the women who are fighting for the most basic rights in the world and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, inviting women to demonstrate without lyjah.
To all my colleagues who have spoken, I say that we are finally talking again and I hope that we will act again soon, also with timely choices of economic policy, of common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by my colleague and the communication by President Tajani.

This choice means some important things. The first, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the maintenance of employment is also and perhaps above all in the recovery and support of the entire economy.
The manufacturing sector, the most advanced sectors and even the traditional ones, because there is a border that can still be addressed and was not so obvious until some time ago.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not at stake in the financial and tertiary sectors, but here, and it is not too late to do so, we can aim for a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness compared to the rest of the world in the industrial sector.

Third point, it has been said that the new industrial policy focuses on factors more than on sectors, it focuses on factors and tools that can really promote new businesses, new capacity for maintenance and updating.

I believe it is important to emphasize these new factors on which we must act, credit. We urge new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the commissioner on the subject of credit, raw materials, energy costs.

innovation, research, the need to emphasize in Europe the ability to transfer technological results of research and innovation within companies, in new products and in new ways of organizing production.

We have to value a very peculiar fabric in our Europe and in some countries in particular, that of SMEs, that of the quality of businesses, the quality of products, in short, the peculiarity of the industry in Europe.
I believe we should rediscover these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries to innovate and change them.
Finally, the issue of territory, which is very important.
European policies are successful if they meet and find the territory capable of addressing them.
So, thanks to Lange, we hope for excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a short time.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles have yet to begin.
Today, the urgency concerns women of other cultures living in Europe and the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this holiday without putting the issue of women in the Arab-Muslim world at the center, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but soon will also become ours.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that are growing year by year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
For a long time, cases of violence of all kinds that Muslim women suffer within their own families have been increasing.

This is why I have been asking for a long time and I am asking it today that Europe implements targeted policies against the spread of Islamic radicalism, against forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We, women and European men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic intellectualism.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the reform of the Constitution that took place on September 12th was unanimously recognized as an important step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken and I express my concern in this regard about the numerous arrests of journalists.

I would like to stress that Turkey is the seventh largest trading partner of the European Union, that the European Union is Turkey's main trading partner, and that trade, correctly interpreted for centuries, has promoted the penetration and peaceful knowledge of peoples.

I therefore applaud the significant progress on the front of boosting connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those through the sea highways that cross the Adriatic and the Tyrrhenian Sea.
There is now a flow of more than 250,000 trucks per year in both directions, in connection with an important railway connection, truck-to-carriage, from port to European internal destinations.
In this way, a significant land transit of trucks on the road could be eliminated and I hope that this will continue.
Mr. President, with today's vote we have given a further impetus to the definitive solution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to remind you that the more than 300 amendments presented in the report have been transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which aim to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, as well as the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, will have to ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and good practices, and the Member States should appoint a high-level government official, hopefully, who will act as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more incisive and less hypocritical if we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should respect in the host countries in the report.
This is my hope, that solutions will be found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all member states.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans, whom the island could never, ever welcome.
Italy has been targeted by hundreds of illegal boats for weeks.
And if we don't react together, if the EU doesn't react, the migratory wave of people fleeing will continue.
The clandestines arrived in the last few months must be sent home, there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond a few words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions. Where is Europe?
Until today, Brussels has been covertly flawless, it has had a shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer stand.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe must not only help Italy in repatriating illegal immigrants, but must also support the efforts of the Italian government to prevent thousands and thousands of people from continuing to leave, especially from Tunisia.

The other speech is instead about the Libyan refugees, on whom Europe must stand by Italy in networking and logistics management operations, but above all it must commit to ensuring that refugees are housed in all member states.
The reception of those fleeing war cannot be the sole responsibility of Italy.
It is time to end it with chatter.
The European Union, if it exists, must strike.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants while France rejects them with shameful methods.
Illegal immigrants must be sent back home, while all member states must commit to welcoming Libyan refugees from now on.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of providing adequate financial resources to guarantee the decommissioning processes of nuclear plants is a problem already addressed by the
European Union legislation on nuclear safety is very topical today, obviously in light of recent international events and the consequent decisions of the Union's governments in this regard.

The work of Mr. Marinescu, to whom we have expressed our support, addresses the specific cases of some countries that, at the time of their accession, have assumed particular obligations in the field of decommissioning nuclear plants and that have received special support from the European Union precisely for this activity.
Beyond specific cases, it is necessary to establish an effective verification control, as well as an examination of nuclear power plants present in the territory of the Union.
In fact, it seems that the number of reactors that are estimated to be decommissioned in the near future in the community territory is high.
It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the provision of adequate financial resources necessary to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the rapporteur.
The report takes into account the innovations that have occurred in the changes in control and communication systems.
This is also why there is a picture of great heterogeneity, particularly on the part of the States in the communication of irregularities and fraud.

The report repeatedly points out the strangeness of low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by several countries in relation to agricultural spending, structural funds and pre-accession funds.
We really need to clarify the statistical data that was provided to us.
The picture is then aggravated by the resulting knot of the ineffectiveness of recoveries.
However, one fact appears clear and confirms a long-term trend.

The fight for legality and transparency in the spending of European resources, such as the fight against the illusion and evasion of income, cannot yet count on the full collaboration of states and governments together with European institutions.
In this sense, I think the requests for a revision of the EU procurement legislation and the need for what I call a European public registry of the beneficiaries of EU funds are appropriate.
I would like to thank the rapporteurs and also Commissioner Barnier for his great willingness towards the Parliament.
We support the idea of an internal market capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
It is not a utopia, it is realism and also modernity.

It is in fact this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because the economic element alone, economism in essence, the reduction of the market to economism, has shown how all this does not solve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
It is, in short, a matter of fully and in the present realizing the pan-European idea of a social market economy.
This is present in today's texts.
There is the recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, ten percent of European businesses and a large part of our employment.
These are realities that are real companies, a demonstration of economic pluralism and business pluralism.

They work with capital, but not for capital, and they want to create work, welfare, quality and social innovation, and to demonstrate that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I am not convinced by Beijing's justification that artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic crimes, nor that such harassment was exercised against a free and dissenting artist.
It is not convincing, as this arrest is part of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression of all dissent.

In the days when Arab uprisings break out, our thoughts go to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against young Chinese who demanded, as they do today with the Gersomino Revolution, freedom and democracy.

China has opened up to the West on an economic level, but without combining production with respect for the environment and labor safety, and it is unable to have any openness towards democracy and pluralism.
Ours is not interference in Chinese internal affairs, as Beijing claims, but the appeal of men and women, movements, and parties that intend to build a world free of intolerance on every continent.
The Beijing government should look at what is happening in the world to understand if, if it doesn't change, it will be the events of history and the Chinese citizens who will change China.
Many jobs lost in the face of several million euros invested in support policies.

This is a dilatory budget in terms of impact on SMEs, in the triumphant Lisbon project first and in the Europe 2020 photocopy strategy, on which it is even being decided to concentrate the resources of the next multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.

I can only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are wondering: what is the point of Europe if it is not able to solve the economic problems of the continent, if it cannot speak with one voice on foreign policy and waste money?
I hope that what Commissioner Tajani has said several times will come true.
I hope that the revision of the SME code will really be able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access to credit recovery, and facilitate internationalization.
With the directive on late payment, a concrete and real goal has been achieved, but it is the result of political will and not of European propaganda.

If the costs of the umpteenth strategy will only finance chatter, I invite the European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small entrepreneurs who, in my region, Veneto, took their lives before seeing their small business fail.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, while Europe pretends to be nothing, Europol's 2011 report on organized crime claims that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian and Albanian criminal organizations will be able to expand their activities throughout Europe.
Again, I quote verbatim, illegal immigration from Turkey will expand to the coasts of Bulgaria, and drug and human trafficking will increase in the hands of Turkish and Albanian crime.

Again, on human trafficking, the entry into Schengen of Romania and Bulgaria could give Bulgarian crime and new Roma communities new opportunities to increase their already significant trafficking to the rest of Europe.
Ultimately, an increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and drug and human trafficking, less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do a great favor to organized crime.
The Northern League party will always be against this kind of wicked choices.
Those who vote in favor of this report tomorrow will be responsible for a vote that will open up to organized crime a highway that leads right to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Amsterdam Treaty, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained more importance.
The focus was on the integration of economic and environmental policy and the inclusion of environmental issues in policies and other sectors.

Among the key sectors are climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, invited the Union and its member states to extend national accounts to the fundamental aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be completed by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system that is suitable for providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this proposal for a regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data and for environmental statistics and other statistical sectors.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, my vote in favor of the Garriga report on the Union's upcoming financial perspectives is based on the conviction that, precisely at one of the most critical moments of the crisis,
It is crucial to insist and win on the indispensability of giving credible tools to the Union, starting with an adequate financial endowment, in the so-called European spirit.
Therefore, the request for an additional five percent for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to give answers to the major issues ahead of us.
to address real problems such as stronger cohesion between regions, greater research and innovation capacity, and a stronger capacity to generate growth and offer employment.

If these are not adequate, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in the cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not cause damage to the other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favor and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the recommendations of this report.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the new Hungarian constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by control bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of power.
Social rights are emptied, the state provides subsidies to those in need only if they agree to carry out public utility work.
Finally, the right to self-defense is enshrined, which allows you to own weapons at home even without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited and strongly discriminatory rules are introduced against homosexuals.
This is contrary to Directive No. 78/2000, which establishes a general framework for the fight against discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are hardly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Honourable colleagues, we are about to vote on a strategic document of great importance that offers a solid reference framework for the negotiations on the financial perspectives after 2013.

Starting from the request for consistency between objectives and tools, between the new role that European institutions are called upon to play after Lisbon and in the face of recession, and the resources that we decide to invest together.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation that emerges from public opinion, from the recipients of EU policies, from European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter in deciding what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
It tells us that cohesion is today a vital link in the European project, an important heritage for all to be safeguarded, protected and renewed.

I am particularly critical of the effort made on this front on the hypothesis of introducing an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the years of recession that we have behind us have.

It has exacerbated internal gaps, making efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe even more important, fighting waste and clearly putting development policy in perspective.
