However, I believe that the challenge of the intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is a challenge that we must accept in order to open a new phase in politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to substantiate the cohesion policy for the more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to guarantee to Europe in the coming years.
I also join in the thanks to Mr. Langen and the other colleagues with whom we worked to finalize this complex report.
I believe that what the honourable member of the European Parliament has mentioned is particularly important.
I agree with Mr. Langen when he said that we want to maintain the scope, the field of application of this regulation, while keeping faith in what was the mandate of the G20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental objective is to bring most over-the-counter derivatives back to regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of

risk and speculation. When you arrive, as has happened, to exchange and insure four hundred million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, you understand what risks we are taking.

That said, however, I would also like to mention two problems: the first problem is the relationship with the Council, the second problem is the organicity of the proposal for reform of the financial markets that we must carry out.

I raise the first problem regarding the Council and I say it very clearly: the feeling is too often that the Council represents an obstacle to doing well and quickly in terms of financial market reform.
I hope that the new Presidency will take on this problem, because on this occasion we must also put our citizens in the spotlight.
The extension of the deadlines is largely due to the positions, difficulties and conflicts that arise in the Council.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second issue is the organicity and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure on OTCs, there is the measure on short selling and more.

I would like to highlight two points: the specific issue of the commodity market, a particular market that requires special anti-speculative interventions, and the problem of the exposure of local authorities in the countries of the European Union to derivatives.
I think these are problems that Parliament must address.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Fukushima accident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the loss of sea and radioactive water six thousand five hundred times higher than the legal limits.
The risk of food products being contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this only applies to fresh products.
No protection rules have been issued for processed products, particularly for boxed fish.
We import three hundred and seventy tons of tuna in boxes, and the main suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia that import fish from Japan.
This means that the boxed fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is essential and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, consumers know where the box was produced, but not where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to fill this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which will not come into force before two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not be effective before three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope, and the hope is that the Polish Presidency will be a contribution to the battle against the Europe of selfishness.
National, without looking to the future, which is a contribution in favor of Europe that really thinks of itself as an integrated reality with a common destiny.
But, as you rightly said in your speech, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and solve.
In this short time, I would like to point out two crucial issues on the economic and financial crisis front.
First issue: the reform of the financial markets.
It is not a technical problem, it is a big democratic issue of our time. The times are too long, we need to close issues like the one related to the reform of short selling and OTCs.

Second point, we are faced with the issue of taxation of financial transactions, we need to get to the heart of the matter, we expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the signing of the Schengen agreements.
No one questions the advantages of free movement, but it must be recognized that the current structure is no longer adequate to current and future needs.

For this reason, the EU member states must all commit to reviewing the mechanisms of Schengen functioning, so that the freedom of movement does not come at the expense of the right security needs of our citizens.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines can also be partly shared, especially with regard to the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily restore border controls in the event of an emergency.
However, we need to see how this will happen and whether the declarations will be followed by facts and above all concrete results.

It will certainly also be necessary to implement a general reform of the European border protection system, especially the external ones, on which Frontex needs to become an agency with real powers of intervention and support for national authorities as soon as possible.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if you don't just want to survive.

The crisis has profoundly affected the real lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being and future of young people and Europeans.

It is not just about values of cohesion and prosperity. To get out of the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, to which, if necessary, one must also cut the nails, giving strict rules to the financial markets.

remedies against the recession, remedies against the unbalanced development model that has put the person one step below profit, remedies against the renaissance nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are its responsibility today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, even new ones, to move forward, to turn on the engines of growth with research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure and work, because without work people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Vaj Beres and her colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a proud Europe aware of its role.
If European leaderships are there, now it is their responsibility to implement them.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent there is a hidden Europe, often invisible or about which we speak as numbers, statistics, sociology and not as people in the flesh, often women and children or the elderly, that is, the most fragile population.
But Europe will not be credible to its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we here want to be consistent in this Parliament and in this phase of Europe's life.

So, if we say that we should base the Union on values, on human rights, I don't think we can stop or cut so drastically a program for those who don't eat, for those who don't have the right to food, access to food.

For an unresolved legal issue, it is an agricultural fund, it is a social fund, and if it will be social, Commissioner, it should not be at the expense of other social programs, but a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
Let's say we want to guarantee food safety for Europeans, but the first right to safety is to have it, food that is healthy.
So, here is our consistency and our commitment.
So let's find a legal solution that gives continuity and that, with the help of non-governmental organizations and volunteering, guarantees the first fundamental human right, that of food.
Mr. President, I would like to support this report and highlight two aspects in particular, one because it is part of the current debate on the
Review of the common fisheries policy and the basic option, which is related to the regionalization of a policy that has shown all its weaknesses in these centralized years.
This regionalization phase has a particular application in the Black Sea.
I believe that the elements contained in the report by colleague Iotova describe a particular situation, but also repeatable in the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea is not different.
In the Tyrrhenian or Aegean Sea, interactions, especially between European and non-European fishing, are often very damaging to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to highlight quickly is the call for a common coast guard.
There is no policy if there is no exercise of control.

Today, controls are carried out through disparate forces in Europe. I believe it is time to understand how one of the first European law enforcement forces, that is the coast guard, can have a common management, a greater correlation and, why not, a single European body.
With this hope, I fully support the content of the report by my colleague Iotova.

Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation related to the activities of offshore oil platforms.
The European Parliament also wanted to express its position on this matter with this report, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
It aims to provide high safety standards for operators in the sector, and to enshrine the leading role of the European Union in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new interventions requested from the Commission in this matter will have to focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellence
in the sector at the level of procedures and avoid the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that would risk moving away from achieving concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to greater accountability of the operating companies, calls for the improvement of communication and information and knowledge sharing mechanisms and hopes for the strengthening and expansion of the role and competences of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved thanks to the negotiation on this text to which we have expressed our support positive.
I would like to thank my colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, and also Commissioner Edegard.
I believe that we are discussing and reasoning here today to really try to achieve a strong European climate policy that can safeguard the economic development and well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been mentioned here, have focused mainly on reducing CO2 emissions.
The proposal highlights how we must also address the fight against other human emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, affecting climate change.

Many things have already been mentioned that I think it is right to keep in mind: today we are able to do it at absolutely reasonable costs, we have the technologies available and, although it is doubtful that it is the CO2 emissions that mainly affect

And although it is doubtful that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are in a much more limited percentage, it is doubtful that their potential is very high and that we can really achieve significant results in a few years, in a few years.
important.

There are signs, the United States was also mentioned by the commissioner, I saw a study that was published on Nature by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce with which I find.

I think there are many points of contact with respect to the analysis made by colleagues, and therefore I imagine that these will also be things that will allow Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, concrete and important position.

I will only end by recalling, as has already been mentioned, that for the extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are living, we have talked about the homeless until a few minutes ago, there is a sensitivity in European citizens that we must take into account.

Obviously, with a sense of priority for jobs, we should be able to also run a communication campaign that explains to citizens what we want to do in the direction of development and their well-being and the protection of jobs.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the single market, free movement, and the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have intervened regardless of a change in our way of legislating, in the European way or in the national way.

We must follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions, and in particular, we must really start a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and individual states.

I would start with our documents, I take the opportunity to suggest a sort of test of clarity on our documents. When we make a white book, a green book, everything must be more understandable and I come to say that the real proposal is perhaps strategic for our Europe and to really start.

This virtuous phase of starting legislation is to allocate a specific delegation to a European commissioner who specifically deals with clarifying legislation and relations between states and Europe itself.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Council representative and Commissioner, first of all, I would also like to welcome positively, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved last June.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures need to be taken at a European level to combat it.
According to Eurobarometer estimates, the vast majority of our European citizens believe that Europe should do more.
How can we be wrong?

In many member states, there has been a lack of political will to fight corruption, just think that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we think about the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens'rights and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it, adopted by the member states to date, are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must give a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis that is weighing on people's lives, on the maintenance of welfare pension systems and on the institutions'ability to guarantee essential services.

Corruption causes the loss of one hundred and twenty billion euros, equal to one percent of the European Union's GDP, every year and takes away resources from the Union and the member states on a daily basis.
They could be used to provide basic services such as education, childhood, employment, transportation, in short, to subtract clean resources to support people.

Therefore, we need to have more courage and more firmness, both in monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and in intensifying and tightening anti-corruption measures at the level of the Union.

In particular, we cannot talk about the fight against corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the package just launched.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters to measure the extent of the phenomenon in the member countries, which is essential to prepare an effective response.
For example, we are in favor of relaunching the EU's network of points of contact against corruption, as proposed by the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not yesterday, it has been around for a few years.
It is perhaps time to take a critical assessment of the policies that have been followed so far. Has everything always been done well?
We have always made appropriate analyses of the situation.
the right approach was chosen
The same European Central Bank, which, as Minister Rostovsky says, saved Europe, has always done well even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates.
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of politics. But is this the only problem?

Of course, if you think we are still at the implementation of July 21st, this should at least suggest that we should prepare and organize the summits and their conclusions better, but politics will always be slower than the markets.
So the point is to look further ahead, to shift the emphasis on the fight against unemployment and development.

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on the indications of growth and development.

The Commission should go beyond its weakness, say that the priority is the fight against unemployment and the creation of jobs, the redistribution of wealth and the public investment strategy, also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains the primacy of the first priority.
It is a world tourist destination and at the same time it is able to value its entire territorial heritage both in terms of environmental protection and competitive capacity.
It is a challenging and not a given, also in light of not only the opportunities but also the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, of other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also noted in the opinion of the committee that we approved in the Regional Development Committee,
To keep together a strong general strategy of the entire European Union on tourism with an enhancement of the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, full involvement from the beginning is essential, in respect of the principle of subsidiarity of regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourist networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of good practices.
I also think that the proposal to identify a European brand that is able to define a high quality of the tourist product is right.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define priorities, especially from a financial point of view, to ensure that this primacy of Europe is maintained in the future.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the financing of research and innovation is one of the greatest opportunities that development and the European economy have ahead of them.

It is in fact about acting on the lever that can trigger a moment of growth and also of new qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who are dedicated to new opportunities of innovation, technology and related professions.
One observation that emerges from this work above all is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that come to practical application.
to create new businesses, to come up with new patents, and not to remain just basic research, just important knowledge, but not such as to really trigger the desire for development.

The second observation is the relationship with local authorities, regions and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial planning and for the meeting between research, universities, centers of excellence and businesses.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, European schools were created with the aim of guaranteeing access to education in their mother tongue for the children of European institution agents who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was created in Luxembourg in the distant 1953 on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive aspects of this form of teaching, fourteen European schools have been created within the various member states.

Although we recognize that the European school system is more of a necessity than a luxury, it is clear that more than fifty years after the creation of the first European school, this system may have obsolete aspects and must in some way be adapted to the new economic and social needs.

I therefore expressed my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Cavada, which calls for greater involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of the Member States called upon to work towards developing and improving the European school system.
It is known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.
Mr. President, in the last decades, the number of natural disasters that have caused the death of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world has increased exponentially.
Last year, within the Development Committee, I followed the work on the report on the European Union's disaster response capacity.
It has emerged how much more needs to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the multiplication of earthquakes, floods and tsunamis.
The European Union's response to the Haiti earthquake, for example, clearly showed the complexity of the existing tools and procedures.

Although the member states and the EU institutions have acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, crisis management has raised a series of problems in terms of efficiency, coordination and transparency.
This is why I voted in favor of the text by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which calls for greater efficiency in all stages of disaster management and greater coordination.
between the involved parties and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlap and time losses that hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
It is just a good initiative, I believe it will be about building a European policy towards tourism.
The European brand is a good intuition, but I want to dwell on two issues. There is no sea or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe it is time for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the conception of the sea and the conception of the coasts is not limited to a sort of urban planning that ends up in the drywall and does not involve the sea as a whole.
I believe that an integrated policy in this sense is useful, as well as building everything that is behind the statements of rural tourism.
It is an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, areas where there is no longer work, where it is important that depopulation does not continue and that there is human settlement.

Well, it is not enough to just make statements, but we should suggest to Europe and individual states to intervene on the fiscal lever. Tourism in rural areas means maybe paying less taxes, maybe this way we really build a real opportunity for the tourism resource and for those who live in rural areas.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my congratulations on the work done by Mr. Fidanza, which logically fits into the framework of the actions of the European Union.
undertaken and promoted at the community level in the field of tourism, after the Treaty of Lisbon assigned the EU new competences for the sector.
I share and want to emphasize the importance of a Europe as a unified destination of certified and quality tourism and the will to promote this
The same idea translates it into actions at the level of structures, resource allocations, funding, coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the countries of the Union.

An approach to be valued and rewarded, given that the sector in question, with its implications in terms of percentage of GDP produced, employment and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises,
Businesses, with attention to environmental protection and enhancement, are able to develop and thus respond to the main challenges posed by today.
For all these reasons, I consider this report positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European tourism policy.
Mr. President, also for the recovery, three small considerations: we need more Europe here as well.
I believe it is inevitable that there is a truly unwanted attitude on some issues, in which not only is there hope, but more Europe is being built.
More Europe means, for example, starting to think about a real common road police, about identical rules from the point of view of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European training policy, not just delegating it to individual states, but building, for example, a real training policy.
In comparison to schools, in comparison to young people, in comparison to categories that are a bit more at risk, motorcyclists were mentioned a moment ago, but we can also talk about truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools inside cars that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-discrimination tools.
I believe that they are a timely strategy to be built with car companies and European car manufacturers.
I believe that if all this falls within the conviction of a common policy, I really think that perhaps the conditions will improve.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, this report addresses a topic that is that of global food security. Global means that this topic is not only that of world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the topic of food supply concerns all communities, including those of the most developed countries.

I will draw some lines, such as the essential one of consistency between European policies and this goal of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often not consistent in its choices.
I just want to outline other titles of three innovative lines that I believe we should develop further.
The first is that food supply is now at risk due to price volatility due to speculation on food products, which must be contained, if not prevented, derivatives, etc.
Second, the issue of land grabbing, which must be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, because democracy is at risk, as well as the survival of many peoples.
Third, consistency between supply and energy policies.
We cannot prevent food from being produced for the people of the world in order to produce new energy.
Mr. President, I voted convincingly in favor of this report by Mrs. Zimmer, first of all for a reason of
It is purely political because I think it is necessary to bring this great issue of food security back to the center of the initiative of the entire European Union.

It is not just a matter of helping developing countries to deal with this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, since it is expected that by 2050 the demand for food will increase by more than seventy percent.

Agricultural products are a major issue that, if not addressed in time and decisively, will become one of the main threats, if not the most important threat to stability, peace and democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is essential that the entire European Union, together with the member countries, makes all the necessary efforts, starting with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to seriously address this major issue.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I must thank all the people who have contributed in these weeks and months to the production of this document that we are voting on today in the chamber.
I must say that we worked very well and a really constructive debate developed.
The motion for a resolution that we are voting on today is the result of truly common work and the contribution of all political forces and the entire Parliament.

I believe that a very strong common sensitivity has developed with regard to this issue, also because we must remember that we live in an era that is really characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we look at them in their crude nature, are very eloquent: the number of disasters in the world has quintupled, if we think that in 1975,
Seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we have almost four hundred calamitous events per year.

Unfortunately, in the last twenty years, there have been ninety thousand victims of these disasters and more than twenty-nine million individuals have been affected by the disasters, while the economic losses amount to two hundred and eleven billion euros.
It is clear that we are facing phenomena of such dimensions that they require a stronger, more effective response and a really strong commitment on our part.
We all have the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan in our eyes.
Europe itself sees sudden floods and fires on its territory every year, let us remember the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
There is no need to go further to state how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
The fundamental principles are our polar stars, the principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause of the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are moving along these lines.
The European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced by the tireless work of our Commissioner Gheorgheva, but today we need to make a leap in quality.
A leap in quality that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to a response where the reaction is.
It should be strengthened through the preventive identification of the existing means in the Member States made available by the European civil protection mechanism.
It is also important to emphasize that for this leap in quality and to move from sharing information and responding to emergencies, the role of planning and monitoring is important.

Coordination, which we hope for, the fundamental role of services such as GMS, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern that exists about what is happening with the budget for these new technologies that are fundamental.
We have included the importance of communication with citizens because the Japanese experience has taught us a lot about this: it is never enough and it is never sufficient.
We are waiting for the Commission, to which we ask to present the proposal on civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.

oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to live their faith in secret, barbarically killed priests without the authorities moving their finger, anti-Western foreign policy, this is today's Turkey.
My party, the Nordic League, has always been against Turkey's entry into Europe because it represents a potential Trojan horse of radical Islamism on our continent.
Today more than ever we are convinced that the EU must put an end to the accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats Turkey has made against Europe must be responded to immediately.
It is not acceptable for a third country to tell Europe what it should do.
Cyprus is a member country, just a member of the EU, and has the undeniable right to take over the rotating presidency.
Europe must give a precise signal and show itself ready to defend Cyprus by all means in the face of Turkey's arrogance and military political arrogance.
We will immediately stop the accession negotiations and also be ready to suspend trade relations.
Mr. President, we are living a decisive step for the future of the euro and, with it, of the entire European construction.
Having this awareness would mean moving away from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological will to rigor the balance of accounts.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without a smart investment policy that can give the economy a boost, there will be no chance of growth.
The only clear result in this setting is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the weakest classes.
That is why, together with the Socialist and Democrat Group, we voted against this report.
In fact, it continues in a single direction, that of austerity without growth, a direction that has proven to be wrong so far.
I really appreciated the work done by colleague Ferrera with this report.
In fact, on the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this, my group and I expressed a positive vote.

We did this because, among other things, a clause for the protection of social rights has been included, starting with collective bargaining, and there is also a strengthening of the role of Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

So, even though we cannot change the overall balance of the six-pack of proposals, this report is certainly a step forward to have, among other things, a surveillance system that takes into account fundamental rights.
And so, in this context, while we are saying that a vision based solely on an austerity policy does not produce positive results, this report is certainly a positive note in the opposite direction.

Honourable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken a stand in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are not able to guarantee effective border control today and are the target of widespread corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
It is not the parties and populist movements that think this way, but Europol in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria were to enter the Schengen area at this time, police and security organizations predict that Bulgarian borders, especially maritime borders, would become an easy target for Turkish crime and Eastern Europe, and Bulgaria and Romania would become the crossroads for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some member states have many reservations about the real ability of Bulgaria and Romania to guarantee effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means opening the way to transnational crime and opening a crossing in European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
There are many opposing reasons and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions of the Commission and the Council are regarding this delicate issue, which in my opinion has been dealt with so far.
sufficient and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail for the competent authorities in the field of international security and crime.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and give the okay only when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have an impact on the safety of European citizens.

Mr. President, the crisis in Europe is intertwining the problems of public budgets and private capital with those of the productivity of our businesses in a vicious circle, and the specter of recession is there.
If the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission that we absolutely, together with Parliament, ensure that our good principles are put into practice.
practice and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Mr. Commissioner, what would it be like if the application of the directive against late payments were anticipated in all member states? What great advantage would it be for SMEs? Then SME tests are important, but we are still at the methodological level.

Of course, it is right to verify if when we legislate we really do it in the interest and in the measure of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we ask that we proceed with great perseverance and tenacity, in depth in creating this framework of opportunity that you have outlined.
We appreciate what the Commission is doing and we are ready to support it with the budget and other possibilities we have.
I will just say a word about credit.
Let's make a clear speech with the banks, I say to you, Commissioner, because we need to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr. President, I expressed my vote in favor of the text of my colleague, Mrs. Wallis.
Although not prejudicing the usual ways of accessing justice, I am convinced that an alternative solution to the ADR dispute represents a quick and economical alternative to legal disputes.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have a significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through joint activity with the member states, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening the citizens'confidence in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report on the provisions for sectors placed on the market in the flexibility regime, to which we expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that was created.

On the one hand, it is to avoid setting unbelievable and impossible requirements to be met, and on the other hand, to prepare a so-called flexibility regime that, by articulating itself in the prediction of temporary phases and corresponding quantitative limits of

The permitted emissions allow the placing on the market of a pre-established annual quota of tractors that meet certain characteristics and thus allow the adaptation to the established standards to be diluted over time without trauma for the relevant production and industrial sectors.

Honourable Tattarella, the work done was important and he was able to strike a careful balance between the needs dictated by the major challenges that the European Union is called upon to face in this period and those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis context.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than the one of the 29th century, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade disparities between countries, financial markets lacking common rules, and the instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, urgently highlights the formal aspect of new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy and stricter supervision policies, and decision-making bodies and international economic organizations must be the main actors at the center of this new approach.
Europe specifically needs a transparent market to reduce the instability exacerbated by globalization, to guarantee broad reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment that this resolution emphasizes to all countries.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I voted in favor of the report by my colleague, Mrs. Matera, which analyzes the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been said, more than five percent of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them and the text approved today supports those policies that can represent concrete help for these women, such as, for example, facilities for the
healthcare, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access to affordable housing and special unemployment benefits.
Only by adopting these measures can the needs of an increasingly significant category be met in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, Mr. President. The budget sets few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy. For this, I thank the rapporteurs.
It is essential to focus on investments and not just on prudent budget maintenance.
The alternative would be to passively assist the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to follow individual interests, but we must finally represent a single, compact subject ready for confrontation.

I welcome the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions in heading two, as well as the funding of the integrated maritime policy should not be at the expense of other initiatives and programmes in the fisheries sector.

This will allow us to implement new policies towards better management of marine resources through research and a widespread exchange of data on fish stocks, imposing new projects that can be used in the Adriatic area as best practices in other marine areas.

I conclude with a small note. In the context of future debates on the CFP, and in particular with regard to the Fisheries Fund, I hope that a greater effort will be made on fisheries control, which is the heart of the fight against illegal fishing, but also the basis for the reconstruction of the States.
that fish are considered a common good.
Mr. President, the economic, financial and social crisis we are going through has clearly highlighted several weaknesses of the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most alarming data, most representative of the current situation, is the almost six million jobs lost in the last three years, data that, as this situation develops, are destined to grow if we do not know how to react quickly and effectively.

The text by colleague Bastos emphasizes that in order to make concrete progress, better synergy between education, training and the labor market is necessary, combined with policies aimed at ensuring a greater response between the demand and supply of this market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I expressed my vote in favor.
I voted in favor of what was presented by Mrs. Angelilli because I am dealing with a problem that, as a mother and grandmother, interests me deeply.
Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse and the disgusting world of child pornography means defending our children and our grandchildren, and consequently defending the weakest.
More prevention, harsher criminal action against those who commit such crimes and more careful protection of children are the key points of the document voted today.
Without a doubt, the path is difficult.

I am thinking in particular of the dissemination of child pornography material via the Internet, which can only be combated with close cooperation between member states, police authorities and providers.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the challenges posed by modernity and the report by colleague Tianan Fidina, to which we expressed our favorable vote, require putting the citizen in his role as a consumer at the center of the economy.

The center of the community debate and remind us that the protection of its interests cannot remain only a principle enshrined at the level of the treaty, but must be a concrete inspiring principle of the European Union's policies.

A protected and informed consumer, made more aware and therefore able to fully exploit the tools and resources at his disposal, able to fully enjoy his rights, must be the ultimate goal of the new European Union strategy for consumer policy.

This strategy must therefore be configured as a broad, comprehensive approach, ranging from the financial services sector to the food sector, from the protection of minors, advertising, and therefore be able to make an important contribution to Europe's social and environmental objectives.
The online gambling sector is constantly expanding with a turnover of several billion euros and many problematic issues to be solved.

Therefore, I fully agree with the adoption of all those measures that are aimed at protecting the integrity of sport, also through greater coordination between the member states and the various sports federations.
Last year, together with my colleague Iacolino, we submitted a question calling for decisive intervention by the EU institutions to prevent fraud related to rigged sporting events.
To counter the possible interference of organized crime in European sports, as in the text voted today, a common definition of sports fraud and harmonization of sanctions at the European level.
For this reason, I expressed my favorable vote today.
This and the next are crucial years for the future and for the unity of Europe.

The work program must therefore fully fit into this logic of extraordinaryity, which certainly means focusing activities on essential objectives, giving more concrete effectiveness to our action, and focusing investments on those forms that can in turn put into practice the needs of the economy.

On the one hand, other private resources, but also, as my colleague said, to see the Commission, President Barroso, if I may have your attention for a moment, to see the Commission also exercise a more active, more direct role towards the realities of some countries and the entire Eurozone and the entire Europe.

We hope for this role of the Commission. I also say this as a representative of a country that is changing its government these days, which is not a technocratic government, but a technical government that shows not the renunciation of political forces.

of politics, but if ever the generosity, and I say this as a force that in my country was to the opposition, the generosity of the parties ready to do what is useful to the country even without direct representation.
So, the theme of stable and fair growth, I believe, should see the theme of support for businesses in two points access to credit and innovation.
The Commission and Europe are able to do this in a concrete way.
At the moment when we recapitalize banks, we help to recapitalize banks, even if it is with public support, we must demand that this credit goes to the real economy, especially to the real economy.
At the moment when Horizon 2020 will be one of the main dossiers, we must do research largely aimed at innovation for businesses, large or small.
The chapter on the digital agenda, which is also very important because the creation of this single market will be a great help for our society.

The policies to combat new and old poverty, unfortunately growing in today's Europe, in the Europe of the crisis of recent years, and also in the policies of austerity, especially by the States, are not enough.

new financial commitments, new resources, both on the European budget, also within the framework of the financial perspectives, and on European policies, as just mentioned by the Social Fund and the ERDF, and in the budgets of individual states.
And above all, we should use the European semester to monitor, year after year, the policies that individual states dedicate to this fundamental challenge.

To make the goal of reducing poverty and social exclusion for about twenty million European citizens credible, it is therefore necessary to have consistency between the considerable resources that Europe must make available, the States must make available and the concrete policies that we can put in place.
It is estimated that about two billion euros will be needed by 2020 to achieve the goals we set for ourselves.
This is the challenge that we point out and put at the center of attention as the Budget Committee: consistency between the financial resources we make available and the policies we implement.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the elderly, women, young people, the disabled and millions of people and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation are in difficulty in our countries.
Faced with this picture, we are here to discuss plans to support the Roma community and housing to be given to immigrants.
We must think about helping categories that are really in difficulty and also giving financial and political support to the family, which is the institution on which our society is founded.
We must help small and medium-sized enterprises suffocated by the crisis, because these SMEs are the real antidote against poverty and the real source of wealth in our countries.
We must give priority to our best forces, not tax them to guarantee migrants a minimum income that Europe wants to lower from the other.
Enough chatter about Roma and immigrants. Now we must give priority to the real excluded.
If we look around us, we will see many of them and we certainly don't need to enter a Roma camp to see them.
To these excluded, Europe must direct its efforts and funds, now more than ever.

Mr. President, I expressed my vote in favor of the text on the work of the ACP Joint Committee, which, thanks to the quality of the work done, has established itself as a key player in cooperation between the north and the south of the world.

As a member of this assembly, I myself participated in the meetings that took place in Brussels and in the work that took place in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It was thanks to these visits that I was able to experience firsthand, as I did in Angola in 2009, the sad conditions experienced daily by certain peoples and at the same time evaluate the efforts made by the ACP to improve things.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasize, at a particular historical political moment, especially for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the ACP has been to strengthen the role of the ACP.

It is of fundamental importance, especially in the context of supervising negotiations for economic partnership agreements, promoting the transparency of these processes and the development of disadvantaged local realities.
Mr. President, I personally find the establishment of a European heritage label interesting.

At a time when, due to the persistent economic crisis, a certain euroscepticism is emerging in many member states, I believe that an initiative of this kind can strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union.

The characteristic element of the European brand is not the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value that it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens on the path towards a better interpuntal dialogue.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in December 2009 I participated in the COP 15 in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament delegation.

About two years have passed and I am sorry to say that the work done and the commitments made in Copenhagen, then formalized in Cancun, will not be enough to achieve the goal of limiting the increase in the average annual temperature on our planet to two degrees centigrade.
Some major emitting countries, such as Japan or Russia, seem to want to disregard their commitments, while others do not seem to give the problem of climate change the right priority.

Today, while expressing my vote in favor, I am aware that only with the great and firm will of the heads of state and governments in the world can we create the preconditions for a comprehensive international agreement.
Internet-related services still have a lot of potential for both the economy and a more participatory and inclusive society.
Today, in the transposition phase of the telecom package, there is a risk of fragmentation of the European framework in national legislation.
The monitoring role of the Commission will therefore be important, and I also say the role of BEREC, which some of us would have liked to see stronger in the definition of the telecom package.

The priorities we want to reiterate in this debate are the guarantee of network neutrality, the development of broadband infrastructure and the development of more open software, the security of access and interoperability of systems, and the promotion of the use of.

digital technologies in the various industrial sectors of services, production of digital content and new services, inclusion of the excluded subjects today, I think of the disabled but not only, defense of information and cultural pluralism.
It will also be ensured that operators cannot block, impose restrictions or discrimination against users and that their transparency in commercial offers and in all their activities is maximum.
Mr. President, we all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times the Court has been increasingly the subject of unfair political attacks.
His arrest warrants have often been ignored and that is why the current budget is not proportionate to the efforts and commitment made.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text approved today, because it is the task of the European Union to take all political, diplomatic and logistical actions to support the Court and guarantee its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Thank you, Mr. President. The phosphates present in detergents for household washing machines end up in water systems, rivers, streams and European lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration of the reproduction of various forms of life, and consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae takes oxygen from other living organisms, it can also produce toxins, destroying fish and plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore expressed my vote in favour of the text voted today because, in order to purify the European water heritage, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is poured into the waters of our continent.
Mr. President, the text presented by colleague Lisek analyzes the possible measures to be taken to reduce defense costs in a period of financial crisis, which weigh heavily on the community budget.
The main proposals concern better coordination of defense system planning, pooling and sharing defense capabilities, and support for research and technological development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur's position that the economic and financial crisis that has hit us can be an opportunity for the integration of the economies of the European Union.
European Union defense policies, giving momentum to develop and finally implement those ambitious reforms that have been at a standstill for years.
For these reasons, I expressed my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, following the Arab Spring and the consequences of it, a review of the European Neighborhood Policy has become necessary.

It is clear that, at the current state of affairs, relations with the countries in question must be more focused on cooperation, so as to ensure the priority of democracy and security on both sides of the Mediterranean.

In this regard, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is fundamental to strengthening mutual respect and tolerance with neighboring partner countries, while promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I naturally voted in favor.
Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday in Florence, an event of extreme gravity occurred that arouses horror and dismay.
Fifty-year-old Armato fired fire at two markets in Florence on five citizens of Senegalese origin, two of whom died and three are now hospitalized in severe conditions.
The murderer then committed suicide.
This is the racist and xenophobic extreme right that wanted to kill people he didn't know, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city and before being elected to the European Parliament, I was the mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, a gold medal for resisting Nazi fascism.
Yet this abominable racist crime happened in Florence, which shows that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest itself anywhere and that one should never think of having erased it permanently.

Mr. President, I ask you to express the condolences of the European Parliament and to reiterate the commitment of this Parliament against all forms of racism and for the respect and rights of every human being.
Mr. President, the management of projects in war zones such as Afghanistan is not directly comparable to the management implemented in the countries of the European Union.
in developed countries or in countries not affected by conflicts, with aid obviously hindered also by the stable security situation.
However, we need to try to understand the reasons for the highlighted gaps in project management and the related risk factors in order to improve the situation as much as possible.
I share the rapporteur's position on this matter, which calls on the Commission to make a more careful assessment of fraud, corruption, and non-compliance with the effectiveness of specific projects.
It is therefore necessary to increase transparency and accountability in the use of Union funds and to help both member states and other donors not to make common mistakes.
Mr. President, we do not have the time to go into details or to address the discussion at the highest level, but I believe we must recognize that there are some points that remain very critical.
I share the concern about this green fund of these times where we will find the resources, but there is still a big question mark and a big concern.
However, to be concrete, we must recognize that this time things have changed in Durban.
The old approach has been overcome, which no longer reflected the real geopolitical situation in the world.
We continue to work on a photograph of the world of the nineties, a photograph that has been a long time old, if we look at it in perspective, projected towards 2050, it is truly unsustainable.
We see that in 2050, among the thirty largest economies in the world, there should be nineteen countries that are still on the list of developing countries.
I believe that this change of pace is perhaps the most interesting fact from a political point of view, and it was also emphasized by our colleague Florence in a timely manner.
I also think that we should not proceed with compartments that are isolated.
Also remembering what Mario Draghi, the governor of the European Central Bank, said the other day in this institution, if we also want to push in this sector towards what are the priorities,
Growth and employment, we really need to be concrete and focus mainly on green economy technologies to really give sustainable development and to respond to the most important needs of our citizens.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Europe is going small, the stock markets are collapsing, the centralist Europe of financial lobbies is breaking down, but the Danish Presidency is opening its semester promising total loyalty to the Commission's plans for the creation of a continental economic supergovernment.
Instead of focusing on measures to be implemented to save the lives of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as a faithful watchdog of Eurotechnocracy in the Council.
I don't agree with other steps at all.
First of all, I don't see how it is possible today to propose as a priority the acceleration of the EU enlargement process towards the Balkan countries.
There are other problems to be addressed immediately before worrying about how to integrate countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then Turkey, the Danish government is pushing hard for Turkey's accession.
Fortunately, Turkey is far from meeting the parameters set by the EU for accession.

But the real paradox is that at a time when the euro is at risk of failure, it should be the Danish Presidency that saves it, a country, Denmark, outside the euro zone, because it has obviously never trusted the euro.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the increase in intellectual property infringements has been recorded in recent years.
The years that have passed risk compromising the intellectual property rights strategy in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.
To counter this phenomenon and safeguard the success of the intellectual property protection policy, it has been proposed to entrust certain.
tasks related to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, established in 2009, to the Office for the Harmonization of the Internal Market.

This is to provide the observatory with human and financial resources to take action against intellectual property violations and awareness campaigns aimed at raising consumer awareness about the risks associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.

The vote in favor of the report represents a moment of great importance in the fight against the trade of counterfeit goods and in defense of innovation, growth and competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as employment and the safety of European citizens.
Mr. President, intellectual property may seem contradictory within itself as a definition, but vice versa, it has great moments of consistency.

I voted in favour of this proposal because its purpose, which is to entrust the European Union's trademark, design and model registration office with some tasks concerning the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, is necessary and indispensable in order to fight against the violation of intellectual property rights.

The main objectives are to increase public and private sector awareness of the impact of counterfeiting and piracy and to inform consumers about the dangers associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.
Based on the 33 compromise amendments, an agreement was reached at first reading on December 19th.
The changes provide that the title of the regulation and the name of the office are not changed in the sense of the European Observatory.
Moreover, the important and fundamental thing is the participation of civil society in meetings.
This will make a moment of synthesis like the one we are about to celebrate with today's vote even more democratic and participatory.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report by Mr. Lechner is part of the framework of actions aimed at improving services for citizens and businesses within the European Union.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is in fact an excellent tool to make communications and information gathering by citizens and businesses more accessible and, above all, faster.
Therefore, Mr. President, I expressed my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, whenever the situation seems to improve, new downgrades of the rating agencies come to shake the trend of the international markets.
Many European companies are in crisis and on the employment front, the number of people, especially the youngest, is growing, who are chronically looking for a job.
If austerity plans and the defense of the euro are necessary measures, even more so are the profound revisions of the labor market at the national level, aimed at reviving the European economy.
Only by relaunching the competitiveness of the European Union will we give new confidence to investors and promote growth and new jobs.
I do not deny that the rights of homosexuals must be protected. What I deny, and this is the case in Italy, is that there are no homosexual families.

Homosexuals will never exist, simply because the family to be protected, which the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, the one formed by a woman, a man and their children.
This seems to me to be a fairly basic thing.
This is the reality in Italy and in the other twenty-two countries.
Mr. President, first of all, I also join the affectionate greeting of my colleague Lechner and also the evaluation of his work, which has proceeded with competence, tenacity and determination.

A very hard job, every now and then this proposal for a regulation got stuck and he withdrew it, started dealing with the Council, the Commission, the Legal Commission again, I think I can be proud of this.
I see that there is unanimous consensus on it.

Coming to our regulation, I am also convinced that it is an important thing. Maybe it is not news in the newspapers, maybe it is not considered high politics, but the construction of the European Union also passes.
through a job of satisfying the interests of citizens in their daily lives and above all of these millions and millions who, living across different states,
They find practices difficult to work out, boring and sometimes touch sensitivities in the heart of a family that politics generally sees with difficulty.
The European Union should be proud to have put this kind of attention at its base.
The solutions that have been proposed are intelligent and new. For example, those who have to make a will have the option to choose between habitual residence or the state of origin.

And this makes a decision more flexible, since there are such profound differences, really very profound, between one state and another, that they could constantly put the issue of succession in difficulty.
However, certainty has also been given to the law, because once the legal solution or habitual residence or country of origin is chosen,

It determines a limitation of the discretion of judges and also a limitation of the conflicts that can arise and therefore a more peaceful way of proceeding in this field, and therefore there is more freedom and more certainty.

And then there is the certificate of succession, we believe that certificates are of little importance, this creates the conditions for the heir to have a condition of greater agility and certainty in relation to all the possible difficulties that could arise for him.
This is a fact that positively characterizes this law.

And then it is true, this law is not perfect, there are problems regarding the executor of the will or not, the feasibility of direct inheritance and so on, but I just want to say one more word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council will approve this text, we hope that it will become a regulation, but we must not put a tombstone on this text, because we cannot even stand with the Council.
We should put England in a different position with Great Britain, because Europe cannot do without Great Britain, and therefore we should proceed to overcome these difficulties later.
Thank you, sir.
Mr. President, the European Union has produced a huge amount of laws and rules to build European law and has created the European area called the Stockholm Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use it makes by citizens, which is very low in numerical and percentage terms.
On the other hand, national judges and national lawyers of individual states have grown up within the law of their own country and have a predominant training in this area.
While we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mentality and who is intrigued with knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before talking about training, we must talk about a great communication to citizens and legal operators so that they become the bearers of this great innovation and grow the ability to want to use the advantages of this right.

But then, above all, it is a bottom-up movement that must be created in the training of the service. You cannot teach like schoolchildren in the judicial training of adult and very highly professional people.

One must stimulate curiosity in dealing with one's own cases, to connect with other colleagues and to find solutions, since today common law and civil law converge, they are no longer as distant as they used to be within legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am glad that the European Commission has convinced itself of these aspects, we ask for a reversal of the trend, more legal studies than judicial training.
There is an example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra, which is very interesting, it is a network of officials in every court who radiate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to do so.
This is the essence of our project, and we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the work done by my colleague Giegold with this initiative report and I also recall that with him and others we share an active presence in the social economy intergroup of this Parliament.

As you know, my political group believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, so it is not just one of many policies, but a policy that characterizes our project.

And in these times, with attacks also related to the needs of cutting public spending, etc., we still defend this convincingly, this priority, we know that it can be the updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it should be maintained, defended and reiterated as a priority.

So I believe that in this same vision we must also value economic entities that do business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and that have a very particular role in the so-called European social economy.

They reiterate that production can be done, good things can be done, and efficiency can be achieved even if profit is not the goal, but for example, employment, welfare, job appreciation and contribution to the life of the local community are the goal.

That is why it is important, I conclude, Mr. President, that Europe makes available the useful tools for an active policy and that a good statute, not the one that is now inaccessible, but a good statute for cooperatives can be a way to help this very important sector.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fairer economic dimension.
And at this moment, where we are going through one of the most serious economic and social crises since the post-war period, the function of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

There has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, which has resulted in an increase in employment, more qualified work and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there is a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must happen by helping and not by creating bureaucratic obstacles.
That is why I voted in favor of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will work actively to solve the problems mentioned.

The rescue of millions of European unemployed people does not depend on the overwhelming assistance offered by the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The data collected highlight that most of the fund's beneficiaries are unable to find a new job, while the more fortunate are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts of only six months.
In many cases, they are unemployed to give up this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The kidney is not a solution and does not plug the disastrous consequences of a dangerously and too lightly managed European trade policy by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of now structural unemployment, Europe must put a stop to its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose unfair competition is the primary cause of the failures of our companies.
As long as Europe does not stop promoting economic self-harm by defending a short-sighted position towards global trade flows, our companies will continue to fail.
The fund can only be a temporary support, but it is not thanks to training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and security.
I believe that today is a great achievement for the European Parliament because what I wrote to the President on July 15th
President Buzek, saying that we must establish an anti-mafia commission, I remember that there were many colleagues from different countries who said that the mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy.

Today, colleagues from the north of all of Europe have recognized that there is a problem of organized crime in Europe and have the will to fight together, I believe it is a great and important fact and I want to thank the President and the entire Parliament.
Thank you, Mr. President, thank you to Mr. Sondal for such a complete presentation.

I would also like to reiterate my solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place on December 16 in Zanusdaen, as well as our concern for the subsequent evolution of the events.

What was originally essentially a trade union warning has degenerated into very serious accidents in which 17 people lost their lives and in the days following the accidents in the arrests of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in everyone's interest, and as Kazakhstan has also demonstrated, to shed light on the events firsthand, and I hope that today's one will be distinguished solely as a positive opportunity for our Parliament to delve deeper into what has happened so far.

and to reiterate our call for an investigation that reassures the international community that responsibilities for the Zanonzeo facts will be clarified and those responsible will be prosecuted in the utmost respect for the principles of legality and the protection of human rights.

The delegation that I have the honor of chairing had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to listen to the explanations provided by the Kazakh authorities and also by some NGOs that are very active in observing the events in this country.
The willingness of the Kazakh authorities to provide explanations, as well as the promises of further clarifications, are certainly positive elements that we should all appreciate.

For this reason, I would also like to emphasize the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance that I would have hoped to find also highlighted in the text of the resolution that we will have to vote on tomorrow.
In my opinion, it would have been appropriate to postpone the conclusion of the official investigations, which would have been useful to accompany an official mission of international organizations.

The undeniable need to clarify what happened and the need to appeal for Kazakhstan to make more and more efforts to improve progress on the path to democracy must also be constantly accompanied by a renewed commitment and an open and constructive dialogue with this country.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I voted in favour of this proposal because it aims to update the regulations of 2004 and 2009 in order to adapt to the changes in the national legislation of the Member States in the field of social security and to keep up with the changes in social reality that affect the coordination of the security systems themselves.

This proposal also includes proposals from the Administrative Commission for the Coordination of Security Systems, whose purpose is to improve, modernize and acquire, in accordance with everything established in Article 72 letter F of the previous regulation.

The changes contained in this proposal are intended to guarantee legal certainty for the subjects concerned and also aim to ensure proper coordination at the level of the European Union of national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes that have taken place at the national level and it was necessary to approve it because it takes into account the recent developments in cross-border mobility that affect the coordination of social security systems.

Mr. President, the credibility of the European Union at the international level and the effectiveness of its human rights policies certainly passes through the condemnation of violations, abuses and violations of human rights.

committed in the context of armed conflicts, disrespect for women, minors, and the weakest in general, and persecution based on religions or beliefs, but it is also of absolute importance to avoid disparity.

criteria between the European Union's human rights policy and other external policies, thus promoting democratization and supporting the fight against social inequalities, especially in times of economic crisis like the current ones.
Mr. President, I would like to thank my colleagues Asenis, Patraoneves, Romeva and their assistants for their substantial contribution to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common good, as it provides fifteen percent of proteins to over three billion people, and the lives of over five hundred million depend on fishing and aquaculture.
This makes it a real global public good.
The approval of this declaration indicates to the Commission a precise path on the need to make responsible conduct widespread, both among fishing communities and in consumer behavior.

The debate on the reform of the common fisheries policy has one more reason today to support actions that will get European policy out of the narrow corner on the methods of resource collection and on a policy of rules all aimed at the internal.
On the contrary, a strategy is suggested for the sea as a privileged place to increase its reproductive capacity, both inland waters and through innovative fishing agreements with third countries.

Besides, all of this is not only about protecting the environment and maintaining biodiversity, but also about responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, and the precise interest of fishermen and our economies.
Thank you, Mr. President.
The 2006 directive, presented by the European Commission in a short time, contains provisions aimed at creating a European risk-sharing instrument.

The goal is, in fact, to address the difficulties encountered by some member states in raising the necessary private funding for the implementation of investment projects that can only be partially financed with the use of public funds.

Although the path to getting out of the economic crisis is still long, I believe the work done to reach a compromise text that has set a ceiling for the funds allocated to the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing instruments is fruitful.
