Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the economic crisis, technological development and demographic changes have changed society and the labor market in Europe in recent years.

To meet future requirements for skills, many people will have to complete higher education, many workers will have to continuously update their skills and knowledge even though they are already employed.

For this reason, I expressed my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Tokes, which aims to modernize higher education systems to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and to promote social, cultural and economic development within the Union.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. I won't go into much detail because I only want to mention a few things in the short time I have.

I believe that this seventh environmental action programme can certainly prove to be a useful tool, but only if it is based on a vision of the future that takes into account the need to maintain a solid European industrial base, which is essential to maintain a decent and acceptable level of employment.
There are things that worry me.
I believe that an absolute priority is that this program ensures the most effective implementation of the existing regulation before even setting a new framework.

I am deeply convinced that in order to face today's environmental challenges, we must base ourselves on future environmental policies that are based on solid evidence and the most up-to-date scientific knowledge.

I am concerned about article 24, which talks about the ecological footprint as an absolute indicator. It represents an indicator, an empirical model of reality, not reality itself, we must keep this in mind.

This has many limitations, it tells us how much we touch the environment, but it absolutely does not estimate, for example, the quality of the environment, so my concerns remain and I invite everyone to take them into account.
When we talk about good examples for citizens, we must have the possibility to create jobs.
With authentic and concrete opportunities for change in everyday life through the internal market, we can really use this example, and we will need many more, obviously, as a result of our work.

It is a good example because, as mentioned, it affects the concrete life of citizens, daily life, and also helps businesses to expand their market, not because the costs are high and the services are not available.

They are not only reduced, but also because they can increase the supply of services and, in essence, also help the economy as a whole. So I believe it is certainly a positive example, a good example.

But you will have understood, Commissioner, that there is a very widespread will in this Parliament, in particular I recall the interventions of two of my colleagues, Mardurell Goebbels, of my group, but also many others.
others who would like this good example to become excellent and for us to start, and this measure is partly provided for, with a zero roaming result, because it is possible.
We are utopian.

No, because a European internal market provides that tariffs are similar between domestic and non-domestic, there is no longer a difference if we talk about a single market and, above all, because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when in 2007 we started talking about voice roaming, the first roaming of the third world we are in.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission, I must acknowledge, to its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

The difficulties were very widespread, they came from those who said that the position of a real market does not provide for tariff regulation, they are political prices, they belong to an old conception of the left, etc. Instead, there were those who said it does not work and so on, it slows the market, but in the end we did it.

The interest of the citizens and the finding that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs led to the fact that the citizens were interested in the fact that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs.
So the world travels, things become more and more possible, that's why I think an even more courageous result is possible.
Last observation, because no more are possible today we had a delegation of Tunisian citizens, I don't know if they are still present.
Perhaps among the many benefits, this extra-way expansion makes us understand that the possibility of using it without being afraid of the costs also helps democracy.

In Europe, there are more than one hundred and twenty million broadband users, at least seventy million citizens who use their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study or simply inform themselves.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favor of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone traffic, voices, data and SMS.
A positive decision because the price reduction program will lead to a 35% average drop in tariffs over the next three years.

However, this is not enough. In a difficult time like the current one, both from an economic and employment perspective, communication, new technologies and innovation are a primary good that Europe must defend with more courage.
Each European citizen must be able to move freely between member states, using the telephone fee established by their national operator.

Enough with fraud and very heavy bills for those who move in the EU. If we really want to give a concrete answer to citizens, we therefore believe in a sort of telecommunications Schengen that no longer imposes different tariffs on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I was part of the European Parliament delegation that went to Sicily last November.
Our head of delegation Cecilia Wistrom wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the Minister of the Interior, the Chancellor, and received a response that gave us quite clear answers.

I want to remind you above all that after that visit to Italy the government has changed and the approach to the situation has also changed, but the situation itself has also changed in the countries from which the migratory flow came mainly.
However, this should not deprive us of the need for a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.
The most significant fact is that Lampedusa is still a non-safe port today, and the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contra di Embriagola following the fire of the
September 2011, which damaged it, but only partially, that is, a destroyed dormitory, one damaged out of seven buildings in the structure, and then the de facto suppression of the project.

Apart from the consideration that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was Tripoli during Gaddafi's time, and this analogy does not seem flattering to me, given that migration flows, although significantly reduced in number, also for seasonal reasons,

They certainly did not stop. It is important that first aid and reception activities work and work in Lampedusa, which is the first landing for those who arrive from the other shore after travel that is certainly not easy or risk-free, and the Somali shipwrecked people who arrived know this well.

In April of this year, after seeing ten people die on the boat they were traveling on, or the twenty who were transferred from Linosa because there was no room in other reception centers, or the eighteen who still live in Linosa in the stadium's toilets.

And the tourist residence in Cala Crete, where they are currently uninhabited, is certainly not a CIE or a Cara, and above all, in the meantime, both the health system and the possibility of applying for asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the good will and good heart of the carabinieri or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.

Having allowed thousands and thousands of people to accumulate against every legal and ethical norm in a place that, due to its capacity and function, could only accommodate a few hundred, is a problem.

The fact that a territory of a few square kilometers, already difficult due to its location and logistical difficulties, was forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own inhabitants is a serious problem.
We must reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension that then led to a situation of extreme tension.
the fire itself. I believe
I believe that the excellent report by my colleague Rinaldi was successful in the Chamber.
I absolutely share the flattering judgment on the report.

Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small issue: our Europe, in relation to this new world that is seeking to find democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to pay, both with regard to environmental aspects and with regard to the economic transactions that are in the Mediterranean.
The Mediterranean is a place of fishing.
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe that will set very strict rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules.
So why not use forms of fishing agreements, support for these countries so that they apply the same rules that apply in Europe?

This would be healthy for European fishing, it would be healthy for the sea, for environmental conservation, to make this split less and less split, but more and more a homogeneous place on which to build the future of Europe and this new world.

After the Lisbon Treaty came into force, the European Parliament became a full institutional subject in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to participate actively and decisively in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the security model of the Union.

The report by colleague Borsellino defines the five key areas for which concrete actions have been proposed and hopes for greater judicial and police cooperation between member states to tackle organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to take into account the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools for ensuring a European area of freedom, security and justice.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations for the development of criminal law integrated into Community law have been laid.

While emphasizing the importance of mutual recognition, harmonization, and the protection of the principle of presumption of innocence, it is good to emphasize how the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, so that it is clear to everyone which action constitutes a crime or not.
This is particularly true for directives that must be mutual in national law.
Any lack of clarity could lead to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent and quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.
The European Union guarantees the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising and abusive contractual clauses.
There is no doubt that those consumers who are more vulnerable for reasons of age, physical or mental health problems or simply lack of due information should be protected more carefully.
I therefore expressed my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Perez because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer rights
The so-called most vulnerable contribute not only to their social inclusion but also to ensuring a safer, fairer and more competitive single market.
Mr. President, the report by colleague Perez, to which we expressed our favorable vote, is about the need to consider the elaboration of a.
a strategy aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
The consumer's vulnerability conditions are due to different causes and can potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside the general consumer and to prepare a targeted strategy in this regard, which, taking into account the complex nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions is not able to consider all the facets of the issue and the different possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other hand, it prevents the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to come to a definition of specific and targeted protection measures.
Thank you, Mr. President. The management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long history, quite complex, since the 90s and is probably the one regulated most strictly by the European Union today.
Despite the significant investments in control that have led to greater compliance with the rules, there are still concerns about the problem of overfishing.
I therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the eligible catch rate, greater control and strengthening of capacity reduction measures.
Mr. President, the relations between the European Union and China clearly show situations of imbalance at the commercial level.
It is therefore the duty of the European institutions to strive to help European businesses to get out of the crisis and to make access to international markets more equitable.
I have therefore expressed my support for this report, particularly sharing the issues raised by the rapporteur and the application of the principle of reciprocity.
relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition on international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the road is still long, but today's can be an important step towards the introduction and application of a financial transaction tax.
I understand the prudence, caution, the need for graduality expressed by Commissioner Scemeta and the technical problems that Minister Vestager rightly spoke about.

But precisely for this reason I hope that the Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to give stimulus and impetus to the necessary initiatives to address the problems that remain open, especially at the Council level.
We all want to carefully assess the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears that can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
For example, I refer to the logic of the exemption proposal.
If you are careful about reducing the impact of the tax, then it is important to have the broadest possible tax base with a low rate and not to try to extend the exemptions unlimited.
To those who are concerned about the effects on small investors, I recall the progressive nature of the tax, which affects those who carry out more operations and more
transactions and it is clear that the competent authorities will have to in any case ensure that the possible costs are not passed on to customers and end users.
I therefore hope that the Parliament will vote by a large majority in favor of this tax.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, since 1990, through the macro-financial assistance instrument, the European Union has granted economic aid in the form of subsidies, loans or a combination of both to countries in difficulty with the short-term balance of payments.
The rather long deadlines, in addition to the difficulty obvious by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some changes to the regulation.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make evaluation criteria faster and more effective and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the granting of macro-financial assistance.
Mr. President, there are about one hundred million European citizens working in various volunteer activities.

From major sporting events to cultural events, the role of volunteers is fundamental, and the work of those people who come to provide help and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters should not be overlooked.
Volunteering is one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I hope for the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of the obstacles that currently exist.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of technology is becoming increasingly important in the fields of communications, finance, transportation, energy, culture and health.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital means makes the problem of cyber security one of the priorities of the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can, in fact, promote economic and social development only if the current rules guarantee user security regarding data confidentiality and intellectual property rights.

For this reason, only full international cooperation involving member states, institutions and industries in the sector can create a solid system capable of introducing effective measures to guarantee cyber security.
Madam President, thank you to the Commissioner, he said important things that I fully agree with.
I find it really, as he said, shocking that we have lived each in our own country with the numbers and figures we heard before from colleague Oconi.
But it is equally clear that this scandal has really highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the current European legislation on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the gaps we have discussed so far in the chamber, which the Commissioner has represented so well, so I would not like to dwell on this aspect in the short time I have available.
I think it is good to do everything necessary so that we can offer our citizens the best.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us many things, could also be a starting point for taking another step forward, and I am referring to what my colleague said before.

The communication that is made for patients is really poor, it is always only emphasized the positive aspect, it is said that there is a sort of eternal youth, of promised beauty, there are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure aesthetic surgery, should be really communicated to people, to girls, because we know that there are very young women who approach this type of surgery.
I see that you are absent with conviction, so I recommend, let's really work, the time is tight, we should have done it yesterday.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the Council regulation on the multi-annual plan for the herring stock was adopted before the Treaty came into force, and therefore an alignment was necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fishing sector to be aligned with the Treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could affect the decision-making procedure applicable to other multi-annual plans.
For this reason, I expressed my vote in favor.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there are numerous environmental disasters that have affected Europe in recent years and put the health of European citizens at risk.

The text by colleague Ader concerns the revision of the Services Directive, which aims to contain the effects of those accidents connected with large quantities of highly polluting hazardous substances dispersed in the environment.

The revised rules, which will come into force from June 2015, are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, limiting the tragic consequences for the health of citizens, and therefore I expressed my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I also thank Stevenson for the excellent work and the approach he has given to this report, which essentially addresses the two main issues.

This is not just a matter of a simple herring management plan, it is essentially about guaranteeing a future for fishermen in some ways and planning in the sea to ensure that this has its protections in a multi-year manner.
But the key point of this report is and remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council should accept the approach given by the Treaty of Lisbon and I also think that it is time for the Parliament, in some way, with a voice perhaps more authoritative than that of the Council.
The debate within the Fisheries Committee or a debate on a report concerning the lines should have the courage to take a very clear and strong position on the issue of delegated acts.
We claim the right that there is indeed the ordinary procedure on these matters.

I am perfectly aware that the issue also involves, among other things, many other fishing sectors that will worsen with the ongoing reform, but it concerns issues related to agriculture and other topics.
The essential step is to respect the will of the Parliament.
The directly affected car companies were not taken into account at all in the drafting of this report.
In Italy, 91% of freight transport is done by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we are committed daily to reducing the financial and administrative burden on our companies, but reports like these undermine the efforts of the European Union.
all our efforts, because they will suffocate the companies themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with ruinous economic losses and with new forms of unfair competition.
It would have been enough to achieve a balanced report that would not forget the right to survival of our companies in a very difficult economic period, but a dialogue of this kind was not possible.

On the contrary, the report has deliberately ignored even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive, and has even ignored the European Commission documents that recognized the danger of practices such as retrofitting, which is instead reproposed in this report.
The document we will vote on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements that have been made in recent years and to pay the costs once again to European companies.

Mr. President, just to say that ACTA was a very serious political mistake, let's leave aside the legal one, it led to a reaction in the world of immense proportions and that is enough to say that it is a political mistake.
Why the benches?
Because it created the suspicion that access to the web was really being closed, which is a great modern revolution.
And why is that?
because he made the mistake of putting counterfeiting and piracy together, which are two clearly distinct phenomena.
The way to fight counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then another mistake that has cut out the Parliament in an important activity that it has been carrying out for a long time, which is to create a new copyright, a new copyright.

The old copyright that existed before the web. So the point is that we must work on copyright and put aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject it and exclude it because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, after months and years of hesitation, the Commission brought two important measures, orphan works and the next one, that on copyright management companies, to the attention of Parliament.
This is the advantage. We work on this by reflecting with our brains and not just with emotion, but without having acta in our feet.
Mr. President, just to add my voice to the applause that this report has received in the Chamber in relation to the need to strengthen the European Union's capacity
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce and produce in the perspective of our conception of an inclusive, socially and environmentally sustainable economy.
So I think some indications here are very useful in this measure, others can be added and I think it is important to collect this indication, to work more and more so that attractiveness is.
The consequence of territorial policies, territorial marketing, and openness, which are, on the part of the territory, the proposal of a productive and industrial vocation.

manufacturing and services that, born from the territory, respect all environmental compatibilities and, together, European policies that go in this direction, from the territory and from Europe, a voice that is attractive for investments and growth.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, when we talk about sensitive issues such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic production, we are talking about the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is important to meet the expectations of consumers regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is also important to ensure the proper application of Community legislation by the authorities, bodies and operators concerned.
That is why I expressed my vote in favor of the colleague's text.
Madam President, honourable colleagues, in the history of the first comments on the Council, the reduction phase has now begun, and this is wrong because important steps have been taken.
For example, think of breaking the destructive ties between banks and public debt, and the despite weak employment and labor plan.

It seems that the spirit of revival and a renewed path of political unity, after so much slowness and torpor, is returning to the European institutions, and there is a will for real progress for greater integration.
Yesterday we recorded a strong unity between the Parliament and the Commission on this.

I am not talking about winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis of the community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from several countries, not to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common consensus that respects all member states.
This is the path of the political goal of unity, without which any banking, fiscal and monetary union will be completely insufficient.
On June 20, with the Council's decision to return the possibility of reinstating border controls to the member states, a new Europe was born, a courageous Europe in fulfilling the desire to.
Greater security for its citizens, finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, reduced to the defense of the rights of its peoples first and foremost.

I would like to say to President Schulz, even though he is not present, that this historic decision does not represent an inter-institutional accident, but rather a respect for the will of the citizens and not for the Euro-bureaucracy that has been pretending for years not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of illegal immigrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants, measured by Frontex, of thirty-five percent in 2011.

I only regret that the scenes of political sterilism spent in this House in the last plenary session have taken time for a more useful and constructive activity, to question why we, the Member States, were not the ones defending the interests of our citizens.

If the Parliament does not find its soul and the courage to go against good sense and the sterile obviousness on which it has been boasting for too long, it will continue to be gregarious and not a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr. President, I would like to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday it was.
officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others and their existence, and this happened in European soil.
Science gives life to our earth, civilization and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to become a capital of world science again.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it, and it is for science and this wonderful ambition of man that today a person
A blind person who doesn't have eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African boy who doesn't have legs can run to the Olympics in a speed race.
Well, Europe must be the homeland of science. This great event that will open new borders to knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not file a complaint due to fear or lack of trust in institutions.
The text voted today aims to strengthen the rights of crime victims and guarantee them the same level of protection, assistance and access to justice.
all the countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who run a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Therefore, the recognition of the victim status is of particular importance not only for people who have suffered prejudice as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the person who died as a result of the crime.
On September 11, the Catalan people demonstrated peacefully in Barcelona.
One million people have asked for Catalonia's independence from Spain.
On October 15th last year, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow a referendum on Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, thousands of people have signed in the past weeks to hold a referendum for the independence of Veneto from Italy.
Yesterday in Venice, Lombardy and all the northern regions, hundreds of thousands of people signed to have more autonomy from Rome.
But even in Flanders and the Basque Country, citizens are calling for a strong voice, autonomy and independence from national states.
What does President Schulz say?
It calls for a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy Vidal Cuadras, worse still, even called for the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are a very serious act, contrary to the principles of that democracy that we preach here and that we should defend.
I tell them that it will be the people who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The road is already paved.
The austerity policy adopted to get out of the economic crisis has not yielded the expected results.
As emphasized by the report by colleague Lavia, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget aimed at
By supporting growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economy of the member states, improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have expressed my vote in favor.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is quite problematic.

With the member states committed to making fiscal adjustments to their respective national budgets to put public finances in order, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that aggravates the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, in order to really get out of the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of education and development.
This is the programmatic paper of an institution. The budget shows what it is, what it does and, above all, what it wants to do in the future.

Today we are faced with a crucial choice between a survival budget, of dragging, maybe a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments for employment, for innovation, for young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation of development.

Everyone should understand that, as colleague Kalfin said very clearly, Europe can do today what states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is established or the lives of citizens we have talked about are destroyed.
The great European choices risk today being suffocated by accounting disputes within the Council, but not only between beneficiary and paying countries.

We say that it is a false problem because it is easy to demonstrate with numbers, not with words, for what has happened in the past, that the contributing countries sometimes benefit more than others from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working on putting figures alongside the various headings.

The war of positions has begun, statements, positions of some states that consider the budget as if it were any expenditure item that can be cut without remorse, indeed perhaps useful to comfort an anti-European sentiment that is easy to stir up in times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position that does not help the integration we are trying to achieve in other fields.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as many of us have said.
We adopted a stability pact that was also supposed to be a development pact, but we have become so stable that we are in recession.
Let us at least seize the opportunity of this budget, of this multi-annual framework, to make choices in the right direction.
The lack of information and awareness of one's rights, which is added to the obstacles to the rights of others, is a problem.
Language problems and the lack of recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems that EU citizens face when they reside, study or work in another EU country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility of the notion of Union citizenship and its concrete advantages.
For this reason, I expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is to strengthen awareness of the rights related to the citizenship of the Union and to help citizens fully exercise their right to move and reside freely in the territories of the member states.
Mr. President, the multiplication of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance and control of their effectiveness.
In fact, a fair balance must be found between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such tools at the European level is, however, of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investments in the economy.
In a real way, in line with its objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in responses to the community budget is opposed to the constant growth of its political ambitions.
The Brussels I regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts of the European Union.
of the Union's legislation, as it has outlined the foundations of a European judicial area, promoted and ensured legal certainty among European citizens.
The recast of this regulation touches on fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of the rules on
on the jurisdiction of disputes with any domiciled persons in third countries and the agreements on the choice of the competent forum.

I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can guarantee a more solid protection of consumers and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I expressed my vote in favor.

Mr. President, Commissioner, today Europe has been asked to take on a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the strictest supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now asking for this role to be exercised.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, even in terms of employment protection, the current crisis will not be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The car crisis is not just about overcapacity, it is about a dramatic loss of employment.
But the crisis seems to be structural now and concerns the very destiny of the car and the product, as it is today.
We want to keep the car industry in Europe and we don't want to disperse existing skills, know-how, and professional skills.
We therefore ask that a large restructuring and revitalization project be started and that it be done in a short time, because the costs are proportional to the time.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual companies.
At least we should try to coordinate and lead this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties to the table through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions and governments of individual countries, offering support for research, innovation, human capital training, requalification, and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task because the national interests of individual companies are not related.

But since the competitive clash in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective impetus and community leadership to face together the increasingly aggressive world market.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the energy crisis has caused and is making a very high price for all employment, for thousands of precarious workers, but also for stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The largest steel groups are increasingly moving towards the Far East or the American continent, and this raises a big question about the direction of our development model.
I think Europe should recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic production capable of providing the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector and the role of a stable steel industry, we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to stop the industrial decline.

I believe we need to move away from a dualism that is not praised here tonight, but is often heard in discussions on this sector, a dualism between environmentalists and workers, which is wrong because it does not show us a perspective of the future.
An industry that sees steel as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard different interests and different needs.

Therefore, we need a strong European project that focuses on sustainability, which I believe we must not go back on as a real added value with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments as has been said.

As I have said many times, new technologies, new processes, the requalification of plants for a European economy that makes an effective use of resources, including energy ones, and also on the search for new and different materials.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December the United Nations Agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done so far, which cannot be questioned, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed by the European Union.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of states around the world are part, many of which are known for a problem related to democracy, transparency and freedom of expression.
So it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the Internet are in danger, that is, freedom, participation, openness, innovation.
Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet, the role that the Internet can play in boosting economic growth, but not only, also to guarantee opportunities for everyone.
I hope, therefore, that the Commission will work with the goal that Europe in Dubai is united and speaks with one voice.

Many of the controversial proposals presented at the World Conference on International Telecommunications negotiating table, particularly those that envisage changes to Internet governance, which call into question network neutrality with negative repercussions on consumers.
Therefore, the freedom of the Internet or, more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection is in danger.
What some states have proposed would allow a government to get its nose into not only its citizens'communications, but even the data that transit through its networks.
The step from limiting freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it contradicts the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text of my colleague, and I particularly agree with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore believe it is necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in the field of jurisdiction for judicial and administrative authorities for legal professionals.
All initiatives in the sector should also be intensified to fully implement the concept of the Union based on the rule of law.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, in recent years the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and oil, has led to an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to face this situation and be less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore have to rely on its possible gas and shale reserves.
In this regard, some member states have already authorized the exploration of shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase if the discovery allows it.
In a context like this, it becomes necessary to monitor the rules related to shale gas extraction within the borders of the Union so that the effects of its extraction are not neglected.
Extraction, undoubtedly valid from an economic perspective, does not create environmental problems for the possible release of harmful substances into the aquifers and the atmosphere.
Mr. President, I believe that today's debate should be an opportunity to speak objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country for the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is undoubtedly an important economic and commercial partner of the European Union.
This is a country that has already started a process of reforms in economic matters and also a democratic process, but it still has a lot to do to complete these processes.

However, it is a country that, with this goal, persists in demonstrating itself ready for new and more solid reforms, and I believe that this is the task of accompanying them by the European Union itself.

This is why I am certain that the signing of this strengthened agreement will allow for progress, because its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure constant assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and I believe this should have been highlighted even more in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that improving progress on the path of democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and mutual open and constructive commitment.

Our goal should not be to put ourselves in a negative position with these and other countries in the face of the lack of immediate change. Our goal should be to support the efforts of these countries to achieve the goal of respecting the principles of human rights.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, in thanking the rapporteurs of the reports that we will vote on tomorrow, just a small step on the push and I agree with what I heard tonight as a unanimous voice from all my colleagues.
But I wanted to focus on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera report, which I welcome and congratulate.

I wanted to say something: with the past common fisheries policy, it has only contributed to increasing the distance between the institutions that regulate fishing and its real actors, namely fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now in Europe, the lack of a real definition of artisanal fishing has penalized those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their own place, their own seas and their own cuisine.

The conviction has grown that the line followed by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen who have been fishing for a couple of years.

For decades, they have operated according to rules that are relevant to the conservation of the ecosystem, which I can only agree with, but which have never preserved the work activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission and will be able to translate into practical acts to the benefit of the fishing microeconomy.
The report, in fact, highlights a series of advantages, the allocation of a minimum amount to small-scale fishing from the European Fund.

Projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole will have to be incentivized, and, Commissioner, it will have to be essential to encourage young people to access the coastal community.

We have discussed this several times in the Commission, because otherwise not only will fishing probably die due to the shortage of seas and fish, but it will probably die because young people no longer approach this sector.
This report is an opportunity to include training and incentive moments for young people who want to get closer to the sector.
Now, Mr. Toia, two minutes. Like many of my colleagues today, I ask the Council, which made this proposal, what do you want to do, gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it or freeze it in the future?
But it is the same Europe that then wants to be relaunched with Van Rompuy's document on integration.
But with what consistency, I wonder, does Van Rompuy lead these two dossiers?

And what consistency can citizens find between the July decisions, employment and growth, the loud calls for hope, for the future of the European Union that we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall in the name of realism, in a perspective of minimal survival?
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to transform the much-praised reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?

These are sincere questions, we would like a clear and honest answer, because there are signs of institutional schizophrenia here that the Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
The Parliament wants consistency, it wants credibility.

The spinning is an unacceptable practice from an environmental point of view, as it threatens the sustainability of some shark species that have been in the world since the beginning of the 20th century.
At a social and economic level, as it implies the waste of a food product with commercial value, as well as from an ethical point of view, as it demonstrates a total lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal that aims to eliminate the derogation from the ban on removing shark fins on board EU fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further guaranteeing sharks the protection they need, will thus allow the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of cutting shark fins in other parts of the world.
